 Notes:  

 Date:  19/10/1996  
 Source:  Listener (New Zealand Listener)
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  40
 Edition:  
 Quote:  <i>A Frigate Bird Sings</i> follows the struggle of a fa'afafine.. trying to understand and redefine her contribution to her Samoan family, now living in New Zealand. "It's an extremely delicate subject.. particularly among older Polynesians, because in New Zealand the fa'afafine are part of the gay scene; they've become much more visible and upfront about something that in Samoa is an accepted part of their culture. I think some Polynesians feel that the fa'afafine have become an embarrassment to who we are."

 Vol / Page:  5
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Boys will be girls in Samoa. That's the theme of <i>Paradise Bent</i>, a documentary about fa'afafine showing this weekend at the Outtakes Film Festival... "Most of the families consider having a fa'afafine in the house an asset, because in the plantations they are men and in the home they are very useful. They do the sewing, the ironing and the cooking and they look after people," says one of the women. Then there is the next generation of fa'afafine who are seen more as drag queens.

 Date:  3/2/2002  
 Source:  Sunday Star Times
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  C13
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Daryla is what is known as a fa'afafine or feminine man... The tradition of fa'afafines, which literally means "like a woman", is unique to Samoan and Tonga culture. A fa'afafine dresses in women's clothes, has a woman's name and talks and walks like a woman. They prefer straight men... My understanding of the fa'afafine tradition was that in Samoan culture, if a family had no daughters, then the youngest boys is treated as a girl and kept at home to help the mother. These boys then grow up to be fa'afafines.
 Notes:

The relationship doesn't end there; under the skin all are part of one of the grape world's most genetically unstable families; the fafafini of the grape world.

 face
 Homonym Number:  1
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: [An extended mining use (cf. OED2 20 b. end of a tunnel or stope at which work is progressing) transf. to bushfalling and gumdigging.] of a tunnel, slope, at which work is progressing'; perhaps influenced by mining

 Quote:  Face and sidling.-S. is generally used in connection with mustering and connotes the idea of steepness or roughness, and is never used when discussing the aspect. You do not say  `a dark s.,' though you often hear `dark side'; but f. can be used in either sense.

 Quote:  face ... NZ open hillside or slope
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1986  
 Source:  Off the Sheep's Back
 Author:  RICHARDS
 Vol / Page:  22
 Edition:  
 Quote:  It was quite a common practice for experienced bushmen, to have a drive'. If you are chopping up a `face' and there is a large tree behind you further up the face, you select that as the `key'. To save time ... you do not waste time by chopping down each tree individually, but just `scarf' and partly chop each tree. When all is ready and you have worked back to the key, you scarf it very carefully. ... If everything goes according to plan it will `drive' the one below, which will in turn drive the next, and so on ...
 Notes:

 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1874  
 Source:  Edward Crewe
 Author:  BAINES
 Vol / Page:  180
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Suppose a piece of timber - a flitch nine inches by twenty-four and sixteen feet long - is on the carriage, and that we intend cutting nine by three-quarter boards. After taking off a `face' cut, setting the gauger rollers, and placing the flitch in position, the man at the head starts the machinery. `Kreash,' says the saw. and in twelve seconds she is out at the other end. The man at the `tail' at that instant reverses the motion of the table, which gigs back.

 Quote:  Within three days of the Government taking power, State Services honcho Michael Wintringham had sent a letter to his new Minister with the words "face doesn't fit" in an attached note... "Face doesn't fit" is a term used to described clauses which have been included in some public service contracts, creating provision for termination of the job if there are irreconcilable differences between two parties.

 Author:  STEVENS
 Vol / Page:  83
 Edition:  
 Quote:  There are several species of lice found on sheep, but those which occur in New Zealand are: 1) the red louse or body louse, or wool louse (Damalinia ovis); 2) the face louse (Linognathus ovillus); and 30 the leg louse (Linognathus pedalis). The face louse is rare and the leg louse more common in New Zealand...

 factory
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: In NZ very often a dairy factory manufacturing cheese, butter,  and other dairy products. Compare creamery; and contrast the meat industry's works. 


 Origin: 
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
 Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1902  
 Source:  Settler's Handbook of NZ, The
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  102
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The factory system is now fairly well established....  It is hardly necessary to point out that all butter and cheese intended for export will have to be factory-made, ... <i>Ibid</i> Classification of Dairies. - Dairies are registered as - `Factories' or `creameries,'i.e., milking at least fifty cows; ...
 Notes:  1892 Murphy in 1902 Settler's Handbook of NZ (Lands Department) 102



 Date:  0/0/1980  
 Source:  Sage Tea
 Author:  WOOLLASTON
 Vol / Page:  56
 Edition:  
 Quote:   [cWW1, Taranaki] ... the cows were dry and our fathers not going to the factory (called that [instead of `creamery'] now that they made cheese there instead of butter).  Hence, factory butter (or shop butter)  as distinct from dairy (or farm) butter.

 Date:  0/0/1985

 Vol / Page:  70

 Date:  0/0/1892  
 Source:  NZ Statutes
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  56 Vict. 30/178
 Edition:  
 Quote:  "Factory" or "creamery" shall mean a

place established for receiving the milk

or cream of cows from the public for the

purpose of manufacturing the same or any

portion of the same into butter or

cheese, or both, as the case may be.

 factory wire
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: The thin wire used to bind the old double-pack octagonal wooden cheese crates was known in Taranaki as factory wire and served the needs of those needing a more flexible No. 8 around the farm. 


 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2:

 Notes:  

 fair
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: adverb
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: completely; thoroughly; unequivocally; forcefully.  (compare real adv.) 


 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
 Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  14/3/1987  
 Source:  Listener (New Zealand Listener)
 Author:  I A GORDON
 Vol / Page:  67
 Edition:  
 Quote:  If you strike something "fair and square" you strike it accurately and with force. A new meaning had been born - complete(ly), forceful(ly). A woman who tells you she is "fair affronted" is (a) severely insulted and (b) from the north of the UK. This usage has found its way into New Zealand colloquial idiom: " It fair gets me down"; "I feel fair sick when I come to think of it"; and (of course) "It's a fair cow" which takes "fair" a long way from its original sense of "beautiful".
 Notes:

 Quote:  I feel fair sick.

 fair burl

 Sense Number: 2
 Definition: used like fair spin! fair do! fair go! as an (esp. children's) exclam. inviting belief, or with query tone, indicating disbelief.

 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  38
 Edition:  
 Quote:  `Cow' is a common word of abuse, not so surprising when so many of the people have to struggle with the beasts. If something is godawful, they'll say it's a `fair cow,' or they'll call a bad day a `cow of a day.' <i>Ibid.</I> 39 <i>Cow </i>- may just mean cow, but may also mean an unpleasant man, woman, or situation. These things may also be called progressively, <i>a fair cow</i>, and a <i>fair adjectival cow. </I>

 Notes:  

 fair go
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: exclamation
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: An interjection, occas. a mere intensifier `be fair, reasonable!', do you mean it?, expressing: (a) an assertion of the the serious truth, genuineness, honesty etc. of the speaker's statement, suggestion, or general attitude; (b) sometimes, according to the tone used, an ironical questioning of the truth etc. of another's statement etc., or as a protest against some action or command felt to be unjust, severe etc.
 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
 Notes:

 Date:  0/0/1962  
 Source:  Australian & NZ English [TS]
 Author:  SYDER & HODGETTS
 Vol / Page:  325
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Don't interfere. Leave the two contestants to have fair fight between themselves. .in 4;`All right everyone! Stand back! Fair go!'  Be sure you present the issue in a fair way as you describe it. `Fair go now. that wasn't all that was said ...'  Be fair in dealing out the penalty, the rebuke, or the blame. `So I said `I think the lads have had about enough. Fair go, they've had all the punishment they deserve.' ...<i>Ibid.</i> 326 A claim to what is right and just, anywhere, anytime. .in 4;`Fair go! Give him a chance, stand back everyone.'  <i>Ibid.</i>  327 Really. Is that so ... Does the same duty as `I see', `Oh' and similar signals given by the hearer to show interest in what the other is saying. .in 4; I've caught 3 and 4 pounders here myself'. `Fair go? I've never put a line in here, never thought of it.'  You surprise me. I would not have expected this. `... and you're to be in charge of that section.' `Me? I'm to be in charge? Fair go? This's all a big surprise to me!

 Vol / Page:  No. 53/60
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The unusual New Zealand fairy lantern, <i>Thismia rodwayi</i>.., is related to orchids, and is the only member of its family to occur outside the topics. For most of the year, the plant exists as a white root devoid of chlorophyll and deriving its nutrients from an association with a mycorrhizal fungus.

The fairy tern now breeds at only four nesting sites, at Papakanui Spit, Pakiri, Waipu and Mangawhai.

 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1942  
 Source:  Maori Place Names
 Author:  ANDERSON
 Vol / Page:  275
 Edition:  
 Quote:  This fungus was used as food [by Maoris] in times of scarcity. It was washed and cooked before it burst when the white mushroom-like sphere becomes an expanded net-work, the meshes covered with an offensive brown slime. ... Its sudden appearance, often after thunder, caused it to be given two very expressive names - tutae-kehua and tutae-whatitiri (ghost-dirt and thunder-dirt [=shit])

 Author:  WILSON
 Vol / Page:  44
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Name give by early South Island fishermen to the Megrim, or Witch, flatfish. This `fake' flounder was frequently caught and kept to hand out to cadgers who frequented the docks in 

search of a few fish from the commercial fishermen just returned from sea. ... Also called Fake Flounder. <I>Ibid.</i> 74  MEGRIM Witch-fish and Fake Flounder are just two names for this skinny, poor-eating, barely flatfish.

 Date:  0/0/1874  
 Source:  TrNZI
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  7/186
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Sawmillers confind men to `fall' kauri only during these

two months.... During these two months, July and August, let them `ring' the trees, that is cut out a ring of bark and sap 3 or 4 inches wide round all the trees they intend to cut down or `fall' during the next 12 months. ... I have no doubt that these serious defects arise from the practice of `falling' the kauri all through the year.
 Notes:  (Firth `On Forest Culture')

 Vol / Page:  195
 Edition:  1962

 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1983  
 Source:  Gold Fossicker's Handbook
 Author:  NOLAN
 Vol / Page:  112
 Edition:  
 Quote:  False bottom: a floor of compact clay or cemented material appearing to be the base of the alluvial deposit but beneath which lies a further, perhaps richer, deposit and the true bottom. 


 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1967  
 Source:  West Coast Gold Rushes
 Author:  MAY
 Vol / Page:  526
 Edition:  1962
 Quote:  FALSE BOTTOM: a movable or floor in a cradle, sluice-box, stamper-box or puddling machine;  a stratum on which alluvial gold rests but which has other bottoms below it. The last bottom is the `true' one.
 Notes:  

 Date:  6/3/1890  
 Source:  Otago Witness
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  12
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The terraces on either side of.. the Kawarau river, if examinedi minutely, will show that the only deposits of auriferous wash have been made at various periods upon clayey sand-drifts (called by the miners "false bottoms").

 family group conference

 family home
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: 
 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: joint family home
 Pronunciation: 
 Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1895  
 Source:  NZ Statutes
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  59 Vict. 20/66
 Edition:  
 Quote:  FAMILY HOMES PROTECTION ACT, 1895... Any owner of land.. may settle such land.. not exceeding, with all improvements one thousand five hundred pounds in value, as a family home.



68(1) The settlor during his lifetime may regulate the occupation of the family home by himself and his family as he thinks fit.  (2) After his death such occupation shall be regulated pursuant to any direction contained in his will.   (3) So far as no such direction occurs.. the widow or husband of the deceased settlor shall, while living, regulate such occupation.


 Notes:  

 family protection
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: a scheme whereby certain close relatives of a deceased person may apply to the court for a larger share of the estate than the will or the rules of intestate succesion give them
 Origin: [none]

 Date:  0/0/1916  
 Source:  NZ Statutes
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  7 Geo.V 8/84
 Edition:  
 Quote:  An Act to make Further Provision for the Raising

and Maintenance of Expeditionary Forces  during the Present War. <i>Ibid.</i> 95 35. (1). If the

Minister of Defence is satisfied with respect to

any family that it consists of or includes two or

more brothers who belong to the First Division of the Reserve,and are not permanently unfit for military service,he may.. give or cause to be given notice to all or any of those brothers to

show cause before a Military Service Board why they should not be called up for service with

the Expeditionary Force.
 Notes:  The act to which the term "family shirker"                       applies

 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  8
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Interesting details are available in

reference to the operation of Clause 35

of the Expeditionary Force Act, popularly

known as the "Family Shirker" Clause.

When it was discovered that the clause

was to come into operation, the Defence

Department was flooded with names of

alleged "family shirkers."

 fan
 Homonym Number:  1
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: A deposit, fan- or cone-shaped, of alluvial shingle brought down when a river is in flood; a similar deposit or slip on a hillside.
 Origin: 
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
 Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1864  
 Source:  Report on the Formation of the Canterbury Plains
 Author:  HAAST
 Vol / Page:  19
 Edition:  
 Quote:   ... Dr Hector and myself, in drawing up a synopsis of the geological formations of New Zealand, have adopted for the formation of those subaerial accumulations the expression `Fan', for those of regular watercourses; and of `Half-cone', for those of intermittent mountain torrents, and we shall for the future use these two expressions.

Canterbury  Plains, 1864' page 22 et seq) I have shown how in post-pliocene times from the material brought down by the enormous glacier torrents forming huge shingle fans at the foot of the glaciers, two bars were thrown across the sea;

 Date:  0/0/1927  
 Source:  Natural History of Canterbury
 Author:  SPEIGHT
 Vol / Page:  62
 Edition:  
 Quote:  One word now universally accepted in geological literature, viz., `fan', was first used by [Haast]. 


 Notes:  

 Date:  14/10/1933  
 Source:  Press, The
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  15
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Fan: Hill creeks in Canterbury and Otago bring a lot of shingle down with them when they are in flood. On steep hillsides this shingle shingle spreads on each side of the creek, narrow at the top and wide at  the bottom. This natural feature is called a fan. In time tussocks 

grow over the shingle and some large fans of 500 to 1000 or more acres contain very good land. (C.) 


 Notes:  (Acland Gloss.)

 Date:  0/0/1988  
 Source:  Forest Vines to Snow Tussocks
 Author:  DAWSON
 Vol / Page:  158
 Edition:  
 Quote:  In the Cook Strait area the grey-leaved spaniard  (<I>Aciphylla squarrosa</I>) is also a common plant on fans.

 fan
 Homonym Number:  2
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number:

 fans
 Homonym Number:  1
 Word Class: exclamation
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: A children's truce or choosing word. Also fangs.
 Origin: 
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
 Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1966  
 Source:  English Language in Aust. & NZ, The
 Author:  TURNER
 Vol / Page:  158
 Edition:  
 Quote:  ... the way to ask for a truce in a game is to call Pax ... At the  school I went to, the word was Fritz, and the truce was terminated  by the call Fritz all over, but we knew that some schools used  Fans (from south-west English dialect fain I or fainits ?). Apparently some New Zealand schools use or have used baldy, which sounds like a variant of English barley. 


 Notes:  

 Date:  5/2/1983  
 Source:  Listener (New Zealand Listener)
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  72
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Thanks to a flood of correspondence, my ignorance is now abated. The commonest truce word in New Zealand seems to be `fans' with a variant, `fangs' ... As children grow up, the words fall into disuse. They are not forgotten. One of my daughters complained that I had not consulted. Her word had been `fans'.
 Notes:  (I.A. Gordon)

 fantail
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: A handsome flycatcher of the New Zealand bush. Pre-settlement North Island writers prefer piwaka(waka) (Markham 1834, Yate 1835);  early more-or-less scientific writers prefer fantailed (less often fantail) flycatcher, or merely flycatcher; fantail as a popular name is attested in 1845 (1854) (Wellington), 1851 (Taranaki) and sanctioned by Buller (1873 (1888)). Also called piwakawaka, tiwakawaka,  shortened from fantail(ed) flycatcher, Rhipidura flabellifera, Pied or North Island Fantail,  =piwakawaka; and <I>R. fuliginosa</I>, Black or South Island Fantail, =tiwaiwaka.
 Origin: 
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
 Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  13/5/1773  
 Source:  Resolution Journal of J.R. Forster, The
 Author:  FORSTER
 Vol / Page:  2/278
 Edition:  
 Quote:  ... Pohebirds, Fantails, Thrushes, Mocking birds, Yellowheads & various other birds inhabit these impenetrable Forests.
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1845

 Author:  GOLDER
 Vol / Page:  37
 Edition:  
 Quote:  ... fantail ...

 Date:  0/0/1898  
 Source:  Austral English
 Author:  MORRIS
 Vol / Page:  141
 Edition:  
 Quote:  <i>Fan-tail</i> ... bird-name applied in England to a pigeon; in Australia and New Zealand, to the little birds of the genus <i>Rhipidura</i> (q.v.). It is a fly-catcher. The New Zealand species are. -->Black F.- <i>Rhipidura fuliginosa</i>, Sparrm. (Tiwaiwaka).  -->Pied F.- <i>R. flabellifera</i>, Gmel. (Piwakawa). In Tasmania, the <i>R. diemenensis</i> is called the Cranky Fantail, because of its antics.

 Date:  20/10/1860  
 Source:  Richmond-Atkinson Papers
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  1/645
 Edition:  1960
 Quote:   ... Read the papers & did Maori, went for about half an hour in the Domain & found a fantail nest (young ones) & a riroriro's with two young ones & an egg. I am inclined to think the egg is a pipiwharauroa's (white, with purple spots at the larger end). Splitting firewood in the afn. I found a fine large centipede - a weri - body brown, with the articulations very plainly marked, legs a pale blue ...  c. have an appetite like a fantail.  See appetite.

 Vol / Page:  53
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The fantail crutch, involving two positions, is physically harder, and in operation is slower  .. the old traditional method of coming in from the hock out to the tail , with the sheep turned the same way as in shearing. This is known as the fantail style.

 Date:  0/0/1843  
 Source:  Travels in NZ
 Author:  DIEFFENBACH
 Vol / Page:  1/29
 Edition:  
 Quote:  In the lower regions the forest was much enlivened by birds. I shot some parrots [fn Nestor meridionalis. Kaka of the natives.], pigeons [fn Columba spadicea, Lath. Kukupa.], and wattle-birds [fn Glaucopis cinerea, Gmel. Kokako.]. Among the branches of the trees hopped the

neat fantail flycatcher [fn Muscicapa flabellifera, Gml. Piwakawaka.], and a social bird of a yellow colour, which has been depicted by Forster [fn Orthornyx heteroclytus, Lef. Popokatea.], and which had much the habits of the finch. <i>Ibid.</i> 1/77 Sometimes, indeed, the mako-mako [fn Philedon Dumerilii] pours forth ... its melodious notes; or perhaps a hawk [fn Falco brunnea] is seen watching the movements of a smaller bird; or the fan-tail flycatcher busy in the lower branches.

 Date:  0/0/1905  
 Source:  Where the White Man Treads
 Author:  BAUCKE
 Vol / Page:  75
 Edition:  
 Quote:  An old-time bay whaling station consisted ... of at least two boats, with their crew of six men each. The headsman, or mate, four ordinary oarsmen, and the harpooner, or `boat-steerer,' who pulled the bow-oar, and drove in the harpoon, and who, when the whale had been struck and `fastened on,' went aft and steered the boat, while the mate took his place, and by repeated lance-thrusts killed it.

 Date:  0/0/1926  
 Source:  Tutira
 Author:  GUTHRIE-SMITH
 Vol / Page:  362
 Edition:  
 Quote:  fn [a fat sheep, fat-stock] 1. I remember shortly after arrival in New Zealand watching the well-known dealer, Andrew Grant, picking `fats.' When asked by me for his hesitancy and

discrimination in regard to several apparently prime blacks, his answer was that they `killed' badly. So many statements, nevertheless, continue to be accepted because it is nobody's interest to disprove them, that this dealer's belief is given for what it was worth. On the other hand, what Sandy Grant did not know of sheep was not worth knowing.

 Date:  0/0/1947  
 Source:  Early Runholding in Otago
 Author:  BEATTIE
 Vol / Page:  44
 Edition:  
 Quote:  In the 'sixties Fairlight was mostly a cattle run, although carrying a number of sheep. There was

beautiful feed on the run, the real sweet native vegetation, and the stock were fattened for the big Queenstown market which came into existence when the hungry diggers rushed the goldfields in the Shotover and Arrow districts in 1862. When the cattle were in prime condition they were described as being `as fat as mud.'

 fat hen
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: [Var. Chenopodium spp., esp. as eaten as vegetables: earliest recorded occurrence.] <I>Chenopodium</I> spp. Also with distinguishing epithets. Also called  goosefoot (transl. of <I>Chenopodium</I>.  =white fat hen, =goose foot, =red fathen ex</i> which are eaten as vegetables.
 Origin: 
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
 Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/3/1770  
 Source:  Banks Journal
 Author:  BANKS
 Vol / Page:  2/8
 Edition:  1962
 Quote:  We also once or twice met with a herb like that which the country people in England call Lambs quarters or Fat hen, which we boiled instead of Greens.  [fn 10] The New Zealand variety of this herb is <I>Chenopodium triandrum</I>. It may be added, as a philogical curiosity, that Bank's words, taken over into Hawkesworth, become in OED the first literary mention of `lambs' quarters', though `fat-hen' is here ignored in favour of a 1795 appearance.

ore-bodies, and calls any rock exhibiting them `favourable' or `kindly' country. ... The cause of the ore is the cause of the `favourable' country, and it is not correct to say that `favourable' country (in the sense used by the Hauraki miners) is the cause of ore-deposition. place in New Zealand during Captain Cook's first visit in 1769.

 feather out
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: verb
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: of a lead, vein, to extend in a feathery manner, growing wider and thinner, sometimes eventually petering out to nothing (perhaps assoc with peter out).
 Origin:

 Notes:  (Fraser and Adams, Coromandel)

 feed
 Homonym Number:  2
 Word Class: verb
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: To lay out rabbit-food (on a block), to accustom rabbits to the same food as a poison-bait. 


 Origin: 
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
 Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1946  
 Source:  There Was Gold
 Author:  MILLER
 Vol / Page:  130
 Edition:  
 Quote:  One professional poacher I heard of used to watch a rabbiter `feed' his block - that is, to cut up pieces of carrot along the intended poison lines so that the rabbits would get used to the feed before the strychnine was applied - and then, after two feeds, he would step in one night ahead of the rabbiter with his own poison and make a kill. 


 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1953  
 Source:  Musterer on Molesworth
 Author:  STRONACH
 Vol / Page:  60
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The rabbits are then `fed'. Carrots, cut with a knife, or minced, or even cut up in a box with a spade, are scattered along the furrow, or `line'. ...The feeding is usually done three times, and the rabbits eat up the carrot each time. On the fourth night the poison is laid ...

 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  382
 Edition:  
 Quote:  While it is pretty well recognised that feed flavours as such will develop in butter, and can be described as characteristic flavours, feed flavours that arise through contamination are a different matter...a dirty milking-machine can create feed flavour. Experiments have isolated the bacterium which causes turnip flavour independently of the purely feed flavour.
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1970  
 Source:  Grasslands of NZ
 Author:  LEVY
 Vol / Page:  336
 Edition:

There was no doubt about the unpleasantness of these feed flavours in the spring, particularly in home-made farm butter.

 feeder
 Homonym Number:  5
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: a worker on a flax-stripper.
 Origin: 
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
 Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1913  
 Source:  Country Work
 Author:  CARR
 Vol / Page:  43
 Edition:  
 Quote:  When the flax arrives at the mill it is weighed and credited to the cutter. The `bench loader'

then takes two or three bundles and puts them in a barrel (heavy end down). He then takes the longest leaves and places them on a bench convenient to the `feeder'. ...[44] The `feeder' takes each blade separately and places the butt end into the `stripper' which takes the green outer covering off. ... The fibre as it leaves the stripper is caught by the `fly boy', who collects enough to make into a hank, which he places convenient for the `shaker'. The latter, with a motion like cracking a whip, gets rid of as much rubbish as possible, after which he places the hank handy for the `washer'. This man places the fibre in a vat, through which ... clean water is running. 


 Notes:

 Date:  15/4/1944

 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  248
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Feeding off is a feature of the fat lamb and wheat growing areas of Canterbury .. Provided the feeding off is done by large mobs of sheep as quickly and evenly as possible, when the soil is in good, dry condition ...
 Notes:  

 Date:  16/7/1945  
 Source:  NZ Journal of Agriculture
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  76
 Edition:  
 Quote:  On good land where spring growth is vigorous light feeding off of cereals with sheep will prevent lodging, increase tillering, and improve the yield. Hard feeding off, especially on the lighter land, where grazing may not be advisable at all, tends to reduce yields. Feeding off is generally carried out in August if the ground is sufficiently dry .. After feeding off the crop should be tine harrowed to loosen the surface.

 Date:  21/9/2002  
 Source:  Dominion Post
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  F3
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Plans are now under way for the magnificent engines to once again steam their way up what was the longest-running fell railway in the world... The fell patent system was developed by English engineer John Fell. In addition to conventional wheels, it equipped locomotives with wheels that horizontally gripped a centre rail, providing extra traction and braking.

 fence
 Homonym Number:  1
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: A barrier of any of a variety of materials which either protects or demarcates (typically a boundary fence) or encloses an area of of land. Often used or combined with a qualifyings epithet which distinguishes the composition or purpose. For (pioneer) fence types see basket-fence, bush-fence,  ditch and bank fence, ditch and sod fence, dog-leg(ged) fence,  hedge and ditch, log-fence, log and stake,  paling-fence, pig-fence, picket-fence, post and rail, post and wire,  post and stake,  rail-fence, ring-fence, scrub-fence, seven-wire, snow-fence,  sod-fence, stab-fence, stake-fence, stone fence, stub-fence  stud-fence, taiepa (fence), wattle fence, wire fence.  See also rabbit (-proof). Cf. fencing terms  dropper, (spinning-)jenny, standard, strainer, stringer, waratah. [AND has entry at NETTING FENCE. chk DNZE at N] 
 Origin: 
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
 Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  14/10/1933  
 Source:  Press, The
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  15
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Fence: (1) I suppose a fence is strictly a made fence of  wire or rails, and a hedge a growing fence, but nine country people here out of ten speak of a gorse fence. (C.) ... 
 Notes:  Acland Glossary

settler-soldiers are at Motat.

 Date:  0/0/1848  
 Source:  Handbook for New Zealand, The
 Author:  WAKEFIELD
 Vol / Page:  376
 Edition:  
 Quote:  During the year 1847, ... about 500 veteran out-pensioners, constituted into a regiment of 

New Zealand Fencibles, have been sent to Auckland at public expense, with their wives and families; ...
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1922  
 Source:  NZ Wars, The
 Author:  COWAN
 Vol / Page:  1/450
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The corps known as the Royal New Zealand Fencibles, ... was a body of veteran soldiers converted into military settlers, established through Governor Grey's efforts as a protection for the southern frontier of the Auckland Settlement. It consisted of discharged British soldiers, about three-fourths of them pensioners, and all men of approved character and physique. The corps was enrolled in England in 1847. The term of service in New Zealand was to be seven years (most of the soldiers became permanent settlers); ... on arrival in the colony each Fencible was given possession of a two-roomed cottage and an acre of land ... The members of the corps

were required to attend six days' drill in the spring and six in autumn, and to attend church parade every Sunday, fully armed, for inspection. ... The settlements in which the pensioners were established were Onehunga, Otahuhu, [451] Panmure, and Howick; these places were practically founded as villages by the Fencibles.
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1963  
 Source:  Armed Settlers
 Author:  NORRIS
 Vol / Page:  36
 Edition:  
 Quote:  After Hone Heke's rebellion ... in 1845, military settlements to provide a bulwark between Auckland and the Maoris had been established, at Onehunga, Otahuhu, Howick and Panmure. These settlers were military pensioners, called `Fencibles' and their villages were to form a ring of husbandsmen trained to the use of arms; a self-supporting guard. 


 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1983  
 Source:  Of Toffs and Toilers
 Author:  BUCKLEY
 Vol / Page:  143
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The first families [of military settlers] reached Auckland in August  1847 on the Ramilies from Tilbury. ... Known as the `Fencibles' - soldiers liable only for home service - they were provided with a house and land at the outpost settlements.
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1976  
 Source:  MOTAT
 Author:  CRESSWELL
 Vol / Page:  86
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The Fencibles were pensioners from

various regiments of the British Army,

all of whom had seen over 20 years of

active service in India, China,

Afghanistan, or other countries. Although

no longer fit for the rigours of overseas

campaigns, they were all under 48 years

of age, of good physique and character,

and quite fit for the garrison duty which

was theirs when they came to New Zealand

in the years 1847-8; a few following in

1852.

 fern
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: as simplex, or as common fern applied to a plant of open spaces, usu. Pteridium esculentum, =bracken; often {?occas.] to <i>Paesia scaberula</i>,  ring fern (q.v. ?2.?. below); occas. to <i>Blechnum spp. </i>. See also bracken, fern-tree, hymenophyllum, lycopodium,  para, polypody, ponga, Prince of Wales feathers,  spleenwort [prob out],  Cf. fire in the fern; land of ferns. See further 1989  Brownsey and Smith-Dodsworth New Zealand Ferns and Allied Plants.
 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: also tree fern
 Pronunciation: 
 Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  21/10/1769  
 Source:  Banks Journal
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  1/416
 Edition:  1962
 Quote:  `... instead of bread they eat the roots of a kind of Fern <i>Pteris crenulata</i>, very like that which grows upon our commons in England.' [fn] The common N.Z. bracken fern, <i>Pteridium aquilinium</i> var. <i>esculentum</i> (Forst.)
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/3/1770  
 Source:  Cook's Journals
 Author:  1/282
 Vol / Page:  
 Edition:  1955
 Quote:  Firn(?) roots they likewise heat ... than beat them out flat ...; these firns[sic] are much alike if not the same as the Mountain ferns in England. [fn] Bracken, Pteridium aquilinum, var. esculentum.

 fern stain
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number:  1
 Definition: a brown stain on the fleece-wool of sheep caused by the powdery spring growth on bracken fern (Pterdum esculentum). 


 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: Rural
 Region: [none]

 Pronunciation:

variety, is a hard-bitten fellow ... The unobservant are apt to lump all fern-trees together, as pongas, or, in the vernacular, `bungers'.

 Date:  0/3/2003  
 Source:  NZ Geographic
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  62/74
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Fernbirds are still common on the New Zealand mainland, but there they are secretive - unlike the confident Snares birds. They have an unusual way of feeding, employing their tail feathers as a prop while using one or other of their legs to lift up twigs and leaves to look for insects and spiders.

They are flimsy-feathered birds, living inconspicuously in manuka scrub or clumps of bracken

...

Codfish Island  Fernbird <i>B.p. wilsoni</i> STEAD, 1936. Stewart  Island fernbird <i>B.p. stewartiana</i> OLIVER, 1930.  Snares fernbird <i>B.p. caudata</i> (BULLER, 1894).  EXTINCT Chatham Island Fernbird <i>B.p. rufescens</i> (BULLER, 1869). OTHER NAMES: <i>Swamp thrush, grass bird, matata.</i>

 fern-crushing
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number:  1
 Definition: using stock or machinery to crush bracken fern prior to burning and seeding for pasture [or to check its secondary growth.]

 fern-crushing
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: 
 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
 Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1891  
 Source:  Rural Economy of Aust. & NZ
 Author:  WALLACE
 Vol / Page:  230
 Edition:  
 Quote:  <i>Fern crushing</i>. Of the fern country, that upon a limestone formation is the best and the least expensive to break in. <i>Ibid.</i>  245 <i>Cattle</i> [bold] are required for jungle or fern-crushing ...
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1926  
 Source:  Tutira
 Author:  GUTHRIE-SMITH
 Vol / Page:  134
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The first care of the settler was to increase his area of grass by the operation known through Hawke's Bay as `fern-crushing' or `fern-grinding,' - words ominous of the part played by the unfortunate sheep, and which will be described later. It is sufficient now to state that after fire had cleared the tangled bracken growth, the ground was surface-sown and kept clear by browsing sheep. As the greatest growth of fern took place during late spring, it was then impossible to have too many sheep. Every squatter in Hawke's Bay was in the 'eighties `fern-grinding,' so that

in those times sheep could not be bought at that season of the year. The result was that every sheep likely to survive the winter was kept, however old and however fleeced. It was at least a pair of jaws, a beast that could bite bracken.
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1947  
 Source:  New Zealand (various authors/titles)
 Author:  BELSHAW

 Vol / Page:  40
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Hence beef-cattle are used for `fern-crushing', that is, for keeping in check the undesirable second growth of bracken fern over large areas of the North Island hills. 


 Notes:  1947 Clark in Belshaw New Zealand 40

 Date:  0/0/1967  
 Source:  Strangers in the Wilderness
 Author:  RICKARD
 Vol / Page:  47
 Edition:  
 Quote:  An operation that seems to have been peculiar to the hill country of Hawke's Bay was the strenuous one known as fern-crushing. [ref. Guthrie-Smith <i>Tutira</i>.] 


 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1981

 Edition:  
 Quote:  But there were no cattle coming up to listen. ... They'd been in there fern crushing, hundreds of acres of bracken. Men'd just walked off that land in the slump but those cattle were breaking it all in again.

Certain parts of Banks Peninsula are natural fernlands which have been in fern for a considerable period.

 Fernleaf
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 2
 Definition: A New Zealander, esp. a NZ soldier in WW1.
 Origin: 
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
 Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1925  
 Source:  Soldier and Sailor Words
 Author:  FRASER & GIBBONS
 Vol / Page:  93
 Edition:  
 Quote:  <i>FERNLEAVES, THE</i>: A familiar term for the New Zealanders. (From the New Zealand badge). 


 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1935  
 Source:  Slang Today
 Author:  PARTRIDGE
 Vol / Page:  285
 Edition:  
 Quote:  [The] following [was] employed by those who served in the [Great] War ... <i>mad money</i>, return fare, it being very generally believed by the New Zealand troops (<i>Fernleaves</i> or, as they preferred to call themselves, <i>Diggers</i>) that every English girl infallibly carried her return fare in case her soldier friend became <i>mad</i>, i.e., acted with excessive freedom of manner;
 Notes:  1935 Mitchell and Strong in Partridge Slang Today 285 



 Date:  0/0/1937  
 Source:  Dictionary of Slang
 Author:  PARTRIDGE
 Vol / Page:  271
 Edition:  
 Quote:  <i>Fernleaves</i>. New Zealanders; esp. N.Z. soldiers: military coll: 1915. F. & Gibbons. Ex the badge of the N.Z. soldiers.

 Author:  BAKER
 Vol / Page:  49
 Edition:  
 Quote:  New Zealanders were <i>Fernleaves</i> and <i>Kiwis</i> [to Australians].  


 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1946  
 Source:  New Zealand (various authors/titles)
 Author:  SOLJAK
 Vol / Page:  8
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The kiwi, like the fernleaf, is now a New Zealand national emblem and provided the name by which Dominion servicemen were popularly known during the war. (The term `Anzac' correctly applies to veterans of World War I.) Appropriately enough, the nickname `kiwi' has also been applied to grounded airmen throughout the Allied air forces.  


 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1984  
 Source:  Gallipoli: the New Zealand Story
 Author:  PUGSLEY
 Vol / Page:  13 and fn
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Indeed it was as New Zealanders that other nationalities identified us [in WW1], not as `Otago' or the `Canterbury boys' but as `Fernleaves' or `New Zealanders' and it made sense to do so ourselves. ... [fn] `Fernleaf' and `Fernleaves' - the slang term for New Zealanders. `Kiwi'  was not used. According to Brophy and Partridge in <i>The Long Trail</i>, Kiwi meant a ground-duty air force man. A `Kiwi King' was any officer fussy about spit and polish, derived from the brand of Kiwi shoe polish.
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1988  
 Source:  Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A
 Author:  McGILL
 Vol / Page:  45
 Edition:  
 Quote:  <i>Fernleaf</i> New Zealander, from the badge worn by WWI soldiers; replaced by `Kiwi'.

them Anzacs for that isn't right.

 Vol / Page:  245

 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1986  
 Source:  Off the Sheep's Back
 Author:  RICHARDS
 Vol / Page:  61
 Edition:  
 Quote:  A bushman always wore a special type of boot known as `ferntights', named because the upper part of the boot was sewn inside the lower leather, preventing sharp stakes from penetrating the seam and tearing the stitching. Round-headed hobnails were replaced with with square-headed `bushman's sprigs'. ... It was essential ... to have a good firm footing and `bushman's sprigs' helped to prevent us losing our foothold on a slippery bank.

 Edition:  
 Quote:  Boiling down works had also been started at Green Island. Merinos were boiled down for their fat and pelts : and as the hind legs of merinos contained no fat they were given away. Jock Graham did a roaring trade in Dunedin by purchasing carrots in the Taieri and tying three of them to a hind leg of a sheep. This was known as a fiddle and he would hawk them through the streets and dispose of them for sixpence.

 field mouse
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: a house mouse when found out of doors (not a vole as in Britain).
 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
 Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1966  
 Source:  Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An
 Author:  McLINTOCK
 Vol / Page:  2/680
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The field mouse of England is a vole, not a true mouse, but here the common house mouse is called a field mouse when it occurs out of doors. So also any rat occurring in streams is called a water rat but the English water rat is a vole, not a true rat. 


 Notes:  (Wall NZ Speech)

 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1972  
 Source:  West of the Tararuas
 Author:  HOY
 Vol / Page:  107
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The former service comprises a Friday

night train to Palmerston North, stopping

at most stations including those within

the suburban area. The latter is a

morning and evening return train from

Wellington on Sunday. These three trains

are all that is left of a twice-daily

service which served the district from

1923 to 1958, and which was known as the

Field's Express after the Member of

Parliament for Otaki (Mr. Field) who

campaigned for their introduction.

 fig
 Homonym Number:  1
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: an old word for (plug of) tobacco, surviving in prison use. Common in early days among traders, sailors and later on stations, etc., surviving as prison usage in Mount Crawford, Wellington, to at least the 1940s: replaced generally by plug. sc. Of tobacco. .ho:a. ?????

 fig
 Homonym Number:  1

 Sense Number:

 Origin:

 Domain: [none]

 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1980  
 Source:  First Offender
 Author:  BERRY
 Vol / Page:  152
 Edition:  
 Quote:  `I got six figs for that load of rubbish' Fig was a curious word, an Americanism that had some how filtered into N.Z [sic] penal institutions and survived. It wasn't slang in the sense that screw and boob were. There was no other word for the cellophane packet that contained around fifty grammes of offcuts and substandard tobacco supplied by the companies. Nobody spoke of a  packet of tobacco - it was always a fig.
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1980  
 Source:  While We Have Prisons

 Notes:  (Kirk)

 fight
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: a war party; early missionary English translation of Maori taua `war party' (frequent in early MSS, letter and journals). 


 Origin: 
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
 Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  23/8/1827  
 Source:  Early Journals of Henry Williams, The
 Author:  WILLIAMS
 Vol / Page:  70
 Edition:  1961
 Quote:  ...the natives came running, and exclaimed, Ka puta te taua, that is, the fight is in sight, or those  for that purpose.  <i>Ibid.</i> 205 Went to Kororarika to see the Chiefs about the fight. ... [ed fn] `The fight' is a translation of taua much used by the missionaries and early settlers. Both the Maori word and the translation mean a `war party' and are used whether the `fight' is a mere local skirmish or a full-scale tribal war.
 Notes:  check also entry for 1827 Aug 23

 Source:  Piraki Log

 Vol / Page:  64

 Quote:  [=taua[????]] this day we was put in suspense at dusk ... five Boats came into the heads ... we first took them for the fight coming from Cloudy Bay but they proved to be boats from Otago ...

 figure-eight
 Homonym Number:

 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
 Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1936  
 Source:  Passport to Hell
 Author:  HYDE
 Vol / Page:  65
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Twenty-one days on bread and water in the Dummy. Seven days in `figure eights'. ... The `figure-eight' is a mild version of the French Foreign Legion's beloved  torture, le crapaud. For a period of hours each day, ranging from two to four, the prisoner's arms are doubly handcuffed across the small of his back, wrists and elbows forced together. No leglocks are used. He can sit, stand, or lie as he pleases.

 filefish
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: leatherjacket
 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
 Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1855  
 Source:  Te Ika a Maui
 Author:  TAYLOR
 Vol / Page:  624
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Fam. Plectognathi. - The <i>Pakirikiri</i>, (balistes,) file fish, is distinguished by two strong spines at the commencement of the dorsal fin, in shape like the letter V, both fronting the head, and standing out from the fin, these are elevated at pleasure, some fish have only one. The Pakirikiri is abundant in the Bay of Islands. 


 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1898  
 Source:  Austral English
 Author:  MORRIS
 Vol / Page:  145
 Edition:  
 Quote:  File Fish Name given in New Zealand to the <i>Monacanthus rudis</i>,  Richards, family <i>Sclerodermi</i>; in New South Wales to species of the genus <i>Balistes</i>. The first of the spines of the dorsal fin is roughened in front like a file. <i>Balistes maculatus</i> is the `Spotted File-fish' of Sydney. It is closely allied to the genus <i>Monacanthus</i>, called <i>Leather-jacket</i> (q.v.), which is much more numerously represented in Australasia. 


 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1938  
 Source:  TrRSNZ
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  68/418
 Edition:  
 Quote:  <i>Cantherines scaber</i> (Forster). Leather-jacket (trigger-fish, file-fish). 


 Notes:  Graham Fishes of Otago Harbour

 Date:  0/0/1956  
 Source:  NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide
 Author:  GRAHAM
 Vol / Page:  374
 Edition:  2nd ed.
 Quote:  ROUGH LEATHER JACKET, TRIGGER-FISH or FILE-FISH (KOKIRI) <i>Parika scaber</i> (Bloch and Schneider) ... This interesting fish has a number of other vernacular names, such as File-fish, and all with a bearing on its construction. The name Leather-Jacket is due to the fancied resemblance to a North American lumber jacket, not unlike the dark brown coloured jumpers used by hikers. The word rough is attached to the name Leather Jacket by fishermen, because the scales are furnished with sharp points which make the skin so rough that one's fingers cannot be rubbed freely in a direction from tail to head without losing part of one's skin, hence the name File-fish.  


 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1966  
 Source:  Sea Anglers' Guide
 Author:  DOOGUE & MORELAND
 Vol / Page:  293
 Edition:  
 Quote:  ROUGH LEATHERJACKET ... <i>Other names: Novodon convexirostris</i>; triggerfish and filefish are used, but should rightly be given to a family of tropical fishes of similar appearance to our leatherjackets; kokiri (Maori).
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1966  
 Source:  NZ Contemp. Dict. (Aust.-NZ Suppl.)
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  615
 Edition:  
 Quote:  <i>file fish n. </i>New Zealand fish, like the leather-jacket. 


 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1967  
 Source:  Marine Fishes
 Author:  MORELAND
 Vol / Page:  24
 Edition:  
 Quote:  LEATHERJACKET [<i>Navodon scaber</i>] ... The names filefish and triggerfish are sometimes used, but more properly belong to a related group of tropical fishes. The Maori name kokiri is still in use.
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1970  
 Source:  Nomenclature of NZ Fish
 Author:  SORENSON
 Vol / Page:  33
 Edition:  
 Quote:  LEATHERJACKET  (a) Scientific name: <i>Navodon scaber</i>. (b) Suggested commercial name[s]: Creamfish (fillets); Leatherjacket. (c) Other common names: Triggerfish; Filefish. (d) Principal localities where taken: Auckland, Tauranga, Tasman Bay.

 Source:  Gold Mining at Waihi (Glossary)
 Author:  McARA
 Vol / Page:  321
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Fill or filling: The material, usually soft rock or clay from near the surface, which was tipped down passes into the various filled stopes, to fill the space from which the ore had been removed and which otherwise might collapse if left unsupported. Some sand filling (tailings from the battery) was used successfully in the Grand Junction Mine.

 fillet
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: a thin piece of wood used to separate timber when stacked. =sticker, =strip.
 Origin: 
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
 Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1948  
 Source:  Accounting in the Timber Industry
 Author:  JEWELL
 Vol / Page:  128
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Fillets; Sometimes called a `sticker' or `strip'. Is a strip of timber or board 1"x 1" or 2"x 1" placed between layers of boards in a pile and at right angles to the boards for the purpose of separating them and facilitating the circulation of air.
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1952  
 Source:  NZ Forest Glossary
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  
 Edition:  
 Quote:  FILLET 1. n. A small dimension piece of timber placed at right angles to the boards in a pile of timber stacked for drying. syn. STICKER, STRIP.

 fin
 Homonym Number:  1
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: 
 Origin: 
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: whale
 Pronunciation: 
 Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1875  
 Source:  TrNZI
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  7/252
 Edition:  
 Quote:  With the true whales (Balaenoidea)[sic] it has the following characters in common: - Baleen elongate and of fine quality; chest and belly smooth; tympanic bones rhombic; cervical vertebrae anchylosed; mandibular ramus without a coronoid process.  To the finners (or finbacks) [fn. Whalers often speak of right whales as finners or fin-fish, from their yielding baleen or `fin', as they term it. [HWO note: is he implying that right whales are true whales but are also (?mistakenly) called finners by whalers: I don't think so.]] it had the following points of resemblance:- Body elongate and slender, the proportion of head being less than one fourth [253] of the length; has a dorsal fin; pectoral fin lanceolate, moderate, and with four fingers; scapula elongate, with coracoid and acromion processes. Its peculiar characters are the small number of vertebrae, 44; the short mandibles and remarkably broad straight ribs with feeble vertebral articulations. 


 Notes:  (Hector Whales)

 Edition:  
 Quote:  The animal [sc. finback whale] has been named by Cuvier the <I> Rorqualus Australis,</i>  or in English, the Rorqual of the Southern Seas. It is very little known to zoologists; and it is only within a few years that its existence has been ascertained by the scientific. The Rorqual of the Northern Seas, it will be recollected, is the largest creature in existence, attaining sometimes to a length of 120 feet, with a circumference of 40.

 Notes:  

 Date:  19/4/1962  
 Source:  Listener (New Zealand Listener)
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  5
 Edition:  
 Quote:  What about giving the lowdown on terms like bailing and finding ... Could you describe the things a good pig dog's required to do? ... There's two types of finders. There's the wind finder and the track finder. The wind finder will take a pig first ... If you've got a good wind finder with you and you're working the right way into the wind, if there's a pig lying anywhere up to 1000 or 1500 yards away he'll be away like a shot ... With a track finder the pig might be on the move and he'll leave a lot of scent on the undergrowth. The dog will immediately pick that up and he'll stick his nose on the ground ... He'll tail off after the pig and stop him some way, nip him in the leg or somewhere else.
 Notes:  (Interview Murphy/Crump)

 Date:  0/0/1971  
 Source:  Statutes
 Author:  BILLING
 Vol / Page:  97
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Sark threw [the dog] half a sausage. `That's my finder,' he said. `He'll find a pig anywhere ...'
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1982  
 Source:  Wild Pig
 Author:  HOLDEN
 Vol / Page:  40
 Edition:  
 Quote:  [The pighunters] had Sandy and Dark, both finders and bailers, to thank for that. <I>Ibid.</i> 156 Pigdogs are classified into three groups: finders, bailers, and holders. The name of each type indicates perfectly what they are expected to do.

 Author:  CARR
 Vol / Page:  145
 Edition:  
 Quote:  At the very outer edge of my hearing were sounds, vague and indistinct yet full of portent. That rousing battle cry, the rallying call of the finders, muted now, yet with its message crystal clear,  had come wafting on the freshening breeze. 


 Notes:  

 finder
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number:  1
 Definition: a pig dog used for tracing wild pigs [either a track finder or an air finder.] 


 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: Rural
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation:

 fingers and toes
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: 
 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
 Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1926  
 Source:  Plant Life in Maoriland
 Author:  CROOKES
 Vol / Page:  176
 Edition:  
 Quote:  There are numerous families of slime fungus in New Zealand, but, unfortunately, they are not particularly easy to find, as they are rather small, and one must look for them in just the right 

kind of place, and choose moist, damp weather. Of course, they are not confined to the bush; one of them may be discovered in vegetable gardens, for it is parasitic on cabbages, causing the disease known as `fingers and toes.'
 Notes:  

 fingerstones
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: marbles
 Origin: 
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
 Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1972  
 Source:  Folkgames of Children
 Author:  SUTTON-SMITH
 Vol / Page:  176
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Knucklebones (K-34) was played in both Europe and Polynesia, independently at first. In the  nineteenth century distinct European [177] and Maori versions were known. More recently, the two types have merged, and today the Maori children, who are mainly responsible for perpetuating the game in New Zealand, include in their games movements borrowed from the European tradition. ... In most of the provinces the game was known as Knucklebones, and it is widely reported as having been played by New Zealand children of European origin until about 1900. Occasionally it was known as Chucks, Chuckstones, Chuckystones, Fingerstones, Hucklebones, Jacks, Jackstones, Knuckles, or Knucklestones. Children still played it here and there throughout the country in 1949, but they knew little about it until plastic knuckles were

imported in 1954 in large quantities and revived the game.

 finish
 Homonym Number:  2
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: ?The double indent around the outer edge of a ploughed field; ?the higher mounded and furrowed part of a paddock where the ploughing has `finished'.

 Register:

 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
 Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/1/1992  
 Source:  NZ Geographic
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  92
 Edition:  
 Quote:  I find that the drowned trees had

probably come from what the Fiordlanders

call a tree avalanche. Because Fiordland

was so thoroughly gouged by glaciers,

there is virtually no topsoil on the

steeper valley sides. Even the fully-

grown forest has only the precarious hold

of a woven skin of roots that stretch

over rock. This net has a weak grip and

if one section tears free it can peel the

forest from the cliff-faces in great

strips. The fall of just one tree can

trigger a tree avalanche.


 Notes:

 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 3
 Definition: Once used in many places in NZ, popularly and indiscriminately, for < I>Pinus sp, esp. P. radiata</I> (formerly <I>insignis</I>; by the 1960s an old-fashioned solecism, since pine trees and timber have become common, and commonly known.

 Quote:  We had our games [c1907]. A favourite was `Monkey', where the contestant climbed one of the fir trees along one side of the ground (still there at the present day) and did a grand traverse of as many trees as possible. It was characterized by noise, boasting, cheating and an occasional sprained wrist. There was cockfighting in which each of two players, mounted pick-a-back, tried

to resist dislodgement.

 Date:  0/0/1947  
 Source:  Native Animals of NZ
 Author:  POWELL
 Vol / Page:  10
 Edition:  
 Quote:  FIRE BRICK (<I>Asterodiscus truncatus</I>). A large and brilliant coloured species taken occasionally by trawlers, operating in the vicinity of the Hen and Chicken Islands and in the Bay of Plenty. It is more plentiful, however, in deep water off the coast of New South Wales, where the local fishermen call it the fire-brick on account of its flaming colours.

 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1941  
 Source:  NZ Slang
 Author:  BAKER
 Vol / Page:  44
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Fire in the fern for trouble or smouldering discontent. The  expression to spread like fire in the fern, used of a rumour and even of an epidemic, is useful as well as alliterative. Dealing with the 

Maori Wars in the Sydney Telegraph as recently as February, 1940, a writer says: `The fire in the fern has now gone out. Justice is being done to the Maori', which reveals that in Australia the phrase is linked with New Zealand.
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1946  
 Source:  New Zealand (various authors/titles)
 Author:  SOLJAK
 Vol / Page:  117
 Edition:  
 Quote:  New Zealanders have coined or adapted many expressions to meet local requirements, as illustrated by the following: ...  fire in the fern: smouldering resentment; generally applied to the Maori wars and their aftermath

 Source:  Folkgames of Children

 Vol / Page:  175
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Some of the typical terms used in marbles referred to the act of shooting and the movement of the marbles. Those related to ways of shooting marbles were cribbing, firsts, fudging, funks, funnicks, funnigans, flunks, forces, knee-high, knuckle-down-stiff, knuckles, and lasts. Terms

connected with the movement of the marbles were: cannons, clears, dead-stick, double-hits, fires, funs, gees, haystacks, in smug, keeps, kills, kisses, lay-ups, manyes, ones, pink, ringer, rolls, scat, screws, skinned, skun, spiders, sported-off, stays, stops, tracks, throughs.

 Sense Number: 
 Definition: loss of bladder control when drunk
 Origin: [none]
 Register:

 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
 Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/9/2000  
 Source:  Off Campus
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  5(3) : 5
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Alvin's letter to <i>Chaff</i> (Alvin being the Massey student who wrote "firetrucks are cool"), was not as harmless as it appeared. "Your 'happy' letter writer Alvin was not referring to the big red firetrucks one sees driving round town," she wrote. "Firetrucking", male student style, is the practice.. of getting so hideously mullocked that control of the bladder is lost. A wet patch on the front and legs of the trousers ensues. This is the signal that a firetruck has occurred."
 Notes:  

 fireweed

 Source:  Weeds of New Zealand
 Author:  HILGENDORF
 Vol / Page:  126
 Edition:  [1967]
 Quote:  WILLOW WEED (<i>Epilobium</i> sp[p].). - This is also called herb willow, swamp willow, and by confusion redshank and fireweed. It is a native that occasionally grows as a weed in or near ditches. The name is sometimes given to redshank [59], and it is true that both polygonum and epilobium grow in damp places, have willow-like leaves and are about 2 feet high.

 Notes:  

 Date:  18/9/1982  
 Source:  Evening Post
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  12
 Edition:  
 Quote:  But the most common name for the first group of New Zealand soldiers to see active service in the Middle East during the Second World War is the First Echelon ...  Soon after New Zealand declared war on Germany on September 3, 1939, a call went out for volunteers for a special force comprising a wide range of army units.  The use of the military term `Echelon' in the sense of first, second or third echelon has puzzled many people. It refers to the position of an army in the form of steps or parallel lines, each line being a little to the left or right of the preceding one. However, the name was given because the main groups of New Zealanders sent overseas in previous wars had been called contingents.  


 Notes:

 Date:  0/0/1876  
 Source:  Colonial Travel
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  203
 Edition:  
 Quote:  At one time, indeed, the Canterbury Pilgrims, as the early settlers were called, `ruled the roost' in social matters. Those who came out in the `first four ships' were looked up to by later arrivals. To have `come over with the Conqueror' bade fair to pale in face of having `come over in one of

the first four ships' In the Southern States of America you claim blue blood by belonging to one of the `first families'.

 first-footing
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: introduced Scottish custom of visiting friends at midnight on New Year's Eve in order to be the first to put a foot within their doorway. 




 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2:

 firsts
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: 
 Origin: 
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
 Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1972  
 Source:  Folkgames of Children
 Author:  SUTTON-SMITH
 Vol / Page:  175
 Edition:  
 Quote:   Some of the typical terms used in marbles referred to the act of shooting and the movement of the marbles. Those related to ways of shooting marbles were cribbing, firsts, fudging, funks, funnicks, funnigans, flunks, forces, knee-high, knuckle-down-stiff, knuckles, and lasts. Terms connected with the movement of the marbles were: cannons, clears, dead-stick, double-hits, fires, funs, gees, haystacks, in smug, keeps, kills, kisses, lay-ups, manyes, ones, pink, ringer, rolls, scat, screws, skinned, skun, spiders, sported-off, stays, stops, tracks, throughs.
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1981  
 Source:  History of Children's Play
 Author:  SUTTON-SMITH
 Vol / Page:  269
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Here are some [marble] terms from Taranaki around 1880-1890: firsts, lay-up, stakes, tips, sticking-taw, nothings, anythings, fade-it, knuckledown stiff, dubs, finking [sic, ?funking], sips, spanning, placing; and from Dunedin School in 1949: knee high, manyies, tracks, screws, nuts, sleets, kills, forces, dig, dubs, cheats.
 Notes:  

 firsts and lasts
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: phrase
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: 
 Origin: 
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
 Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1953  
 Source:  Unorganized Games
 Author:  SUTTON-SMITH
 Vol / Page:  2/769
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Action terms which refer to the shooting of the marbles are: Knuckle down Stiff, Knee High, Funks [Flunks sic] or Funnicks, Slips, Firsts and Lasts and Forces. ... The term `Knuckle down

Stiff' (Taranaki [18]80, Gisborne [18]85, Waitara [18]95) is mentioned by [Lady A.B. Gomme Vo. 1, p.113]. ... As Taranaki [18]80 says, `The term was called out in order to prevent too easy a success against a marble near the ring'. It was less advantageous to fire with the hand on the ground than with the hand elevated, perhaps at `Knee High'.

 fiscal envelope
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: a Government limitation on the total amount of money payable to Maori claimants under the Treaty of Waitangi settlements
 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
 Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  29/8/2003  
 Source:  Dominion Post
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  B5
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Such is the opposition to the proposals, some believe the issue could be more heated than the "fiscal envelope" hui of the mid-1990s, the last time Maori and the Crown met head on... The fiscal envelope was the term given to the then-National Government's plan to limit Treaty settlements. It was eventually dumped.
 Notes:  

 Date:  14/1/1995  
 Source:  Listener (New Zealand Listener)
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  33
 Edition:  
 Quote:  To Smith it was simply a classic piece of radical publicity seeking, designed to focus debate on the government's now-famous "fiscal envelope". which would settle all Treaty claims for $1 billion in 10 years.
 Notes:  

 Date:  13/5/1995  
 Source:  Listener (New Zealand Listener)
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  26
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The fiscal envelope is like Selwyn Toogood's old quiz show, except it's called 'Money <i><and</i> the Bag.'
 Notes:

 Source:  Dominion
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  10
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Maori expectations of big financial settlements soon rose so rapidly that Jim Bolger's ministry introduced the "fiscal envelope", limiting them to $1 billion.
 Notes:

 Source:  Dominion

 Vol / Page:  2
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The Maori leaders at those huis in the early 1990s conveyed to Parliament such strong messages as their opposition to the billion-dollar fiscal envelope.

 Date:  8/2/1997

 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  28
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Officially, the fiscal envelope - that sought to place a billion-dollar cap on Treaty settlements - is dead.... Yet the rest of the agreement suggests that, although the dread words "fiscal envelope" may no longer be utttered in decent company, the underlying process is really still alive and kicking.

 Author:  BELL
 Vol / Page:  
 Edition:  
 Quote:  If the fishing is to be carried on by a shore party, the try pots and huts are erected on the beach ... The boats are sent out at daylight every morning, and when ... they kill a fish it is towed ashore and flinched and boiled upon the beach.
 Notes:  1831 Nov Bell Letter in 1913 McNab Old Whaling Days 9



 Date:  0/0/1838

 Register:

 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1860  
 Source:  Gatherings of a Naturalist
 Author:  BENNETT
 Vol / Page:  408
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Europeans call the [Horoeka] the `Fish-bone tree', from the peculiar appearance of its foliage. 


 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1866  
 Source:  Polynesia
 Author:  ANGAS
 Vol / Page:  36
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The <i>Aralia crassifolia</i> or fish bone tree is a curious object in the New Zealand woods. It runs up with a slender stem to thirty feet, having tufts of leaves thrown out near the top, which are about a foot in length and an inch in breadth, of a thick, coriaceous texture, irregularly jagged at the edges and abrupt at the end.
 Notes:  [F. Bennett 1860 = LANCEWOOD]

 Vol / Page:  
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The great mainspring of activity at Waikouate, and in these southern parts generally, is Mr. John Jones, of Sydney, who has, for many years, been engaged in the New Zealand oil trade. Most of the fisheries thereabouts are fitted out by him; and he is the principal purchaser and exporter of the oil caught along the coast.
 Notes:  1844 Monro Notes of a Journey (Nelson Examiner July 20 et seq.) in 1898 Hocken Contributions 241 [sc. whale]

 Edition:  
 Quote:  I have heard `fish-head' used only in the Army and on Public Works. It refers to those several steps above the speaker in rank. ... the  glazed eye. One's immediate superior may be quite intelligent and not a bad fellow but, everyone knows, the man above him is always a damn fool.

 fish-hook
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: in the metaphorical and extended sense of an objection or difficulty in the way of a scheme, policy or proposed course of action which could "impale" it and cause it to come to grief.
 Origin: 
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]

Some members of Government expected that the mill would be erected from the 'five per cents' the proceeds from sales in certain

designated blocks, for which.. the construction of flour mills was an explicit objective.

 five wounds
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: catchfly
 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
 Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1926  
 Source:  Weeds of New Zealand
 Author:  HILGENDORF
 Vol / Page:  74
 Edition:  1967
 Quote:  CATCHFLY (<i>silene [gallica]</i>). Varieties of this species have  been named <i>S.anglica</i> and <i>S.quinquevulnera</i>. [1967 quinquevulnera] Commons names are spotted catchfly, flycatcher, sticky weed, and five wounds. It is common in cultivated land and waste places such as gravelly river-beds throughout both islands. ... The flowers are white or often dark red, or sometimes white with a blood red  blotch on each petal so that this variety is called <i>quinque vulnera</i>, `five wounds'.

 Date:  0/0/1991

 Author:  QUINN
 Vol / Page:  95
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Five-eighths. A positional term used almost exclusively in New Zealand; other countries used 'stand-off', 'fly-half', or 'outside half'. It originated with the 1903 New Zealand captain, Jimmy Duncan.

 Date:  0/0/1908  
 Source:  British Rugby Team in Maoriland
 Author:  BARR
 Vol / Page:  36
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The TEAMS.  Britain. - Full back ...; three-quarters - Gibbs, Ponty Jones, Chapman; half backs, Davey and W. Major; ...  Otago. - Full back ...; three-quarters - Dwyer, Bennet, O'Sullivan; five-eighths, McLeod and Dansey; half back, Eckhold; <I>Ibid.</i> 165  The two half back system, which was afterwards to develop into the now well-known five-eighths, prevailed very largely about 1880 ...
 Notes:  

 Date:  15/6/1954  
 Source:  Press, The
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  12
 Edition:  
 Quote:   [It is stated that in 1889 Alhambra came from Dunedin to play Merivale and played only one half-back instead of two. The man who would have been the second half-back `stood between [the half-back] and the three-quarters line.' The Club had no name for the new position, and some discussion took place about it. The argument was ended when a Merivale player said that if the new position was between half and three-quarters, he must be five-eighths. The name was adopted.]
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1968  
 Source:  Pagan Game, The
 Author:  SLATTER
 Vol / Page:  44
 Edition:  
 Quote:  see WIPER KICK <i>Ibid.</i> 172  Woodened out the five-eighths with a straight arm tackle.

 Date:  0/0/1982  
 Source:  Collins Concise English Dictionary
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  420
 Edition:  
 Quote:  five-eighth n. Austral. & N.Z. a rugby player positioned between the half-backs and three-quarters.
 Notes:  [cf. 1986 NZPOD 283]

 Date:  0/0/1938  
 Source:  Rugby Players Who Have Made NZ Famous
 Author:  STONE
 Vol / Page:  89
 Edition:  
 Quote:  James Duncan, of Otago,.. instituted the two five-eighths system in New Zealand.
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1992  
 Source:  Our National Game
 Author:  PALENSKI
 Vol / Page:  26
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The pivot for most of Alhambra's attacks [sc. in a game in Dunedin between Kaikorai and Alhambra in 1890] was the extra player between the halfback and the three-quarter line.  After the game players from both sides sat around discussing tactics and a Merivale back, one F. Childs, is credited with coming up with the new name, five-eighths. A blacksmith, Childs obviously thought logically. If the player was not a half and was not a threequarter, he said, he was between the two and therefore must be a five-eighth.
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1982  
 Source:  Blue and the White, The
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  12
 Edition:  
 Quote:  One of our well-known members Fred Childs gave the player between the halfback and three-quarter back the name of five-eighth which has been adopted throughout New Zealand ever since.
 Notes:  Fred Childs, blacksmith of Makikihi, b. about 1865. No other information

 Date:  0/0/1984  
 Source:  Boots of the Bamas
 Author:  HENDRY
 Vol / Page:  37
 Edition:  
 Quote:  He wasn't a half and not a three-quarter so someone said he must have been a blooming five-eighth, and this is reported to be how this position first started.
 Notes:  

 Date:  21/8/1899  
 Source:  Taranaki Herald
 Author:

 fizgig
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: 
 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
 Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1949  
 Source:  Dictionary of the Underworld
 Author:  PARTRIDGE
 Vol / Page:  247
 Edition:  1961
 Quote:  An informer to the police: Australian: since ca. 1910. In, e.g., Partridge 1937, and Sidney J. Baker, A Dictionary of Australian Slang, 1942 (and, a year earlier, in his new Zealand Slang). Often shortened to fiz(z): Baker, 1945. By contemptuous euphemism; not unrelated to thingamyjig. Baker (1945), however, points out that it may derive from fizgig, Australian for `fishing spear': cf. therefore, spear, v., 1.

 flag
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number:  1
 Definition: danthonia and other green feed that has gone to seed. 


 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: Rural
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
 Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1927  
 Source:  Sheep-Farming, Fencing etc.
 Author:  MCKENNY
 Vol / Page:  15
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Frequently the surplus grass runs to seed and afterwards there is a great deal of what graziers call 'flag.' This flag is neglected by the sheep; they prefer the shorter green grass. In danthonia country, therefore, as in rough bush country, it is profitable to run a limited number of cattle among the sheep. They clean up this rough 'flag', break through bushy and rushy obstacles and thus purify the pasture for the sheep.
 Notes:

 Date:  0/0/1780

 Author:  SEWARD
 Vol / Page:  11
 Edition:  
 Quote:  First gentle Flora ... [12]/ Thin folds of *vegetable silk, behind,/ Shade her white neck, and wanton in the wind;/ Strange sweets, where'er she turns, perfume the glades,/ And fruits unnam'd adorn the bending shades. [fn] Vegetable silk.- In New Zealand is a flag of which the natives make their nets and cordage

 Quote:  He did not like radio commentaries because he did not have the type of mind that could readily visualise the game from such crescendic cliche[acute]s: the pouring into the twenty-five, the piling into the ruck, the try was on all the way.  Notes:  

 flagged
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: adjective
 Sense Number:  1
 Definition: [of a high country sheep] with wool ripped from its back by a kea or by rough handling. 


 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: Rural
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
 Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1993  
 Source:  Farming Under Aspiring
 Author:  ASPINALL
 Vol / Page:  131
 Edition:  
 Quote:  .. sheep up to a kilometre away would run in a startled manner and many of these would be flagged. 'Flagging' is a name coined where a sheep has had the wool pulled up on its back as if grabbed by a hand or in this case pulled up by a kea's beak. One winter some 38 sheep died and another 200 flagged.
 Notes:

 flag-man
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number:  1
 Definition: [early aerial weed-spraying] a flag-waving man on horseback used to direct a plane to boundaries of weedy areas. 


 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: Rural
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
 Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  5/7/1951  
 Source:  NZ Farmer
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  07
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Because of this [the height of the plane] the flag-men are important. At Kapiti Station six 'flag-men' were used, working in pairs. Two pairs gave the aircraft the marks to run in and out, and the this pair then had time to move into a new position. From eight to ten men were engaged on the job during the progress of the spraying, including some of the station shepherds who acted as flagmen to direct the pilot on each run.

 Edition:  
 Quote:  From 1844 to 1847 the `red tribe' fought the first New Zealandwar, against Hone Heke, and his allies. The `Flagstaff War', as it is sometimes called, followed a build up of disappointment, frustration, and suspicion, amongst the northern tribes, in the years immediately following the signing of the Treaty of Waitangi. <i>Ibid.</i> 13 The "Flagstaff War" began on 8 July 1844 when Heke and his warriors ascended the hill above Kororareka and chopped down the flagstaff from which  the Union Jack.. was flying.
