 flannel-leaf
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: Verbascum thapsus, Aaron's rod, golden rod, mullein, native tobacco, tobacco  plant, velvet, wooly mullein
 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: mullein
 Pronunciation: 
 Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1926  
 Source:  Weeds of New Zealand
 Author:  HILGENDORF
 Vol / Page:  155
 Edition:  1967
 Quote:  FLANNEL LEAF (<I>Verbascum thapsus</I>) is commonly called mullein in England, and is frequently so called here as well. Its commonest local name is probably tobacco plant, or native tobacco, a name for which there is no justification in either appearance or use. Velvet mullein, woolly mullein, golden rod, and Aaron's rod are other appellations, but flannel leaf, one of the common sheep-station names is both descriptive and distinctive. The plant is found in dry soil and river beds ... in both islands.
 Notes:  

 Date:  22/11/1974  
 Source:  Dominion
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  5
 Edition:  
 Quote:  VERBASCUM THAPSUS, a weed of poor land has many popular names. In New Zealand it is called native tobacco, velvet, flannel leaf and golden rod.

 Notes:  (Note on Language)

 flapjack
 Homonym Number:  2
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: a seaweed
 Origin: 
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
 Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1961  
 Source:  Flora NZ
 Author:  MARTIN
 Vol / Page:  5
 Edition:  1929
 Quote:  A little lower down where the seaweeds are permanently submerged we have such plants as the GRAPELET, the WIRE- WEED, and OX-TONGUE; the FLAP-JACK and GIRDLE WEEDS. In rather deeper water ... we have the (<I>Lessonia</I>) and the OARWEED, the GRAPEWEED, and numerous representatives of the red algae. <i>Ibid./</i> Flora 14  The commonest of the four species is (<I>C[arpophyllum]  maschalocarpum</I>) which has been designated by the apt and appropriate name of FLAP-JACK from the habit of the plant in swaying first in one direction and then the other as the water enters or recedes from the surge

channels between tidal rocks.
 Notes:  

 flapper
 Homonym Number:  1
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: flapjack
 Origin: 
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
 Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  4/5/1863  
 Source:  Journal and Letters (Walker)
 Author:  WALKER
 Vol / Page:  
 Edition:  
 Quote:  You ask if we had pancakes on Shrove Tuesday [on the Molyneux diggings]. I do not remember what we had on that day, but if there was no meat to be had, I think it very likely what are called here flappers, that is flour and water mixed up thin and fried. in fat. They are very good with sugar. 


 Notes:  

 flapper
 Homonym Number:  2
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: the gen. English (possibly dialectal in Britain) sense `fledgling wild duckling' (1773) used in NZ since 1856; used also in the Chatham Islands ca1972 of fledgling albatross; also of fledgling swan
 Origin: 
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
 Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1960  
 Source:  Back-Country Tales
 Author:  MASTERS

(d) Principal localities where taken: Napier, Wellington, Nelson, Picton, Banks Peninsula, Timaru, Greymouth.

 flash
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: adjective
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: ostentatious, showy, sensational (US); used frequently in NZ coll in various senses most of which correspond to equivalent senses in gen. English, though many NZ uses have derog. overtones a. (i) =British posh: of appearance, dress: modish; smart; ostentatious, showy (NZ 1874: OED 1784); of an hotel: fashionable; expensive; smart (NZ 1930: OED 1840) also of people, `smart'; of meals `well presented, expensive')

 flash note
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: 
 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
 Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1972  
 Source:  From Beads to Banknotes
 Author:  HARGREAVES
 Vol / Page:  40
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The [Governor Fitzroy's (1844)] Debentures, popularly known as `government rags', were given various nicknames such as assignats, `shinplasters', and `flash notes'. All these terms had reference to worthless paper money, some of which had been issued in the past.  Assignats was the name given to large amounts of paper money issued in France during the French Revolution,

but which depreciated to such as extent to be almost worthless. `Shinplasters'--sometimes written `skinplasters'--had its origin in North America, and again referred to depreciated paper money, while `flash notes' was a popular term in use for any counterfeit money or worthless forged paper money.

 flashing
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: occas. wrongly (or vaguely) applied in NZ to roof-guttering; rather than to the standard sheet lead or iron, etc. used to make a waterproof- joint between, for example, a chimney and a roof

 flat
 Homonym Number:  1
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: (usually plural) any area of level land, usually low-lying near water: `river flats'. -->[AND [spec. use of flat a piece of level ground] esp alluvial formation; and esp. as a Source of alluvial gold: see also river flat (river 2.) 1799 damp flats b. with a distinguishing epithet e.g. an appetree flat] note collocation with level
 Origin: 
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]

 Date:  0/0/1874  
 Source:  NZ Sheepfarming
 Author:  CAIRD
 Vol / Page:  26
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The words `terrace', and `flat', so often used, rather aptly to describe the general nature of the country. A flat means a plain, but it is a rare thing to gallop along a flat for more than a mile without coming across a terrace, which terrace may be only 6feet, high or it may be a hundred ... [and] is certain to be as regular as if it formed part of some ornamental ground. 


 Notes:  (Canterbury/Otago)

 Vol / Page:  
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Flat Pack: ca1942 I have only heard this term used by one or two trampers from Otago. Wellington trampers, so far as I have observed, used the term `frameless' pack' if they don't say `kidney rotter'.
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/9/1958  
 Source:  Tararua
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  27
 Edition:  
 Quote:   The two main varieties of packs are the <i>frame pack</i> and the <i>frameless pack,</i> sometimes called a <i>flat pack</i>. The frameless pack of course receives that name only on formal occasions, being more familiarly known by that elegant term,<i> kidney-rotter</i>, or less frequently as <i>kidney-buster, kidney-crusher, kidney-sweater or kidney-rider. </i>
 Notes:  Ruth Mason `Track and Trail'

 flatfish
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: any of a group of side-swimming fish, such as the flounder, having a flattened body and both eyes on one side of its head.
 Origin: [none]

 Source:  Reeds' School Dictionary: NZ Suppl.
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  173
 Edition:  
 Quote:  flat fish: edible fish.
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1956  
 Source:  NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide
 Author:  GRAHAM
 Vol / Page:  210
 Edition:  2nd
 Quote:  NEW ZEALAND LEMON SOLE <i>Peltotretis flavilatus</i> Waite. The Lemon Sole, like the Common Sole, Flounder, Brill and Turbot is a bottom-dwelling fish with both eyes on the upper surface of the body, known as the right side. This fish and the others mentioned are known to fishermen, auctioneers, retailers and the public generally as Flatfish. Skate and Electric-ray are also Flatfish, the upper and lower surfaces being the back and belly. 


 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1981  
 Source:  Fisherman's Bible
 Author:  WILSON
 Vol / Page:  71
 Edition:  
 Quote:  FLATFISH ... Inhabitants of sandy or muddy, shallow flats the flatfish are also occasionally taken in deep water. This is specially so of the fairly rare Turbot which grows to a considerable size and inhabits the deeper, southern waters.

 Quote:  Flathead <i>Kathetostoma giganteum</i> Haast
 Notes:  1955 Whitley Namelist in 1956 Graham NZ Fishes 409 



 Date:  0/0/1956  
 Source:  NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide
 Author:  GRAHAM
 Vol / Page:  286
 Edition:  2nd
 Quote:  FLATHEAD <i>Kathetostoma giganteum</i> Haast ... Other names for the Flathead are Chinaman and Frenchman, but where these names originated and for what reason I do not know with certainty. One theory is that when Chinamen hawked fish about Dunedin they kept Flatheads for their own consumption, as they preferred them to all other fish.  


 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1957  
 Source:  Sea Anglers' Fishes of NZ
 Author:  PARROTT
 Vol / Page:  143

 Quote:  THE FLATHEAD <i>Kathetostoma giganteum</i> Haast. <i>Ibid.</i>169 Flathead Kathetostoma giganteum Puffer-fish
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1967  
 Source:  Animals of NZ, The
 Author:  NATUSCH
 Vol / Page:  224
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Family  URANISCOPIDAE. The flathead, <i>Kathetostoma giganteum</i> ..., is usually found on its own, often burrowing in the sea bed with just the eyes and mouth showing. It shares this way of lifeq (and its wide heavy heady, flattened on top, eyes staring upwards) with the stargazers and catfish. Some fishermen call it chinaman. 


 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1970  
 Source:  Nomenclature of NZ Fish
 Author:  SORENSON
 Vol / Page:  37
 Edition:  
 Quote:  MONKFISH (a) Scientific name: (i) <i>Geniagnus monopterygius</i> (ii)  <i>Kathetostoma giganteum</i>. (b) Suggested commercial name[s]: (both) Whitefish. (c) Other common names: (both) Monkfish, Monks, Stargazer, Flathead (also applied at times to export gurnard); Churchills, Toebiters, Bulldogs, Spotted Stargazer, Maori Chief (Dunedin); Muddies. (d) Principal localities where taken: Napier, Cook Strait, Nelson, Banks Peninsula, Bluff-Stewart Island. ... Monkfish is a general term for species of the Families Uranoscopidae and Leptoscopidiae.
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1981  
 Source:  Fisherman's Bible
 Author:  WILSON
 Vol / Page:  100
 Edition:  
 Quote:  FLATHEAD No relation to the ubiquitous Australian flathead who comes in several forms, most of which belong to the family Platycephalus. The New Zealand flathead is a gruesome, seldom-seen fellow called  <i>Kathetostoma giganteum</i>.

 Quote:  The hoki are sent down first and are by far the major species caught in this area designated G in New Zealand's exclusive economic zone. But there are also ling and school shark, headed and gutted before they are boxed, squid and silver dory, fat blue nose and silver warehou, hake and sharp-toothed southern kingfish, ugly green monkfish and slimy flathead, electric skates and others with saw toothed snouts.

 Date:  0/0/1986  
 Source:  NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide
 Author:  PAUL
 Vol / Page:  118
 Edition:  
 Quote:  <i>Monkfish Kathetostoma giganteum</i> ... Also occurs in southern Australia. Known by a number of local names: giant stargazer, flathead, bulldog, boof, etc. The name monkfish is well established for this species in New Zealand, whereas overseas it is used for similarly shaped but unrelated anglerfishes.

 flatsheet
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: 
 Origin: 
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
 Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1978  
 Source:  Gold Mining at Waihi (Glossary)
 Author:  McARA
 Vol / Page:  322
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Flatsheet: A steel plate, usually four feet square and up to three-eighths of an inch thick, used on underground rail junctions instead of points and on the floor of the brace and shaft chambers to enable the handling and turning of ore-trucks. A considerable amount of skill and strength was required to handle the loaded trucks, which weighed 25 cwt, on these flatsheets. The trucks were built with two-thirds of the weight on the front axle to enable a man to lift the rear-end while turning the truck.

 flax

 Author:  GOVERNOR MACQUARIE
 Vol / Page:  
 Edition:  
 Quote:  A proposal was some time since made to me .. of forming a settlement at their own expence on the northern island of New Zealand, for the purpose of collecting the flax plant of that country,

and manufacturung it .. the projectors of the flax speculation on New Zealand still intend to prosecute their design; and .. send a party of men .. on board the brig Experiment, to New Zealand, where that vessel is to remain long enough to give them time to collect a quantity of dried flax to be sent Home for the inspection of His Majesty's Ministers ...

 Date:  0/0/1930  
 Source:  Fifty Years In Maoriland
 Author:  PINFOLD
 Vol / Page:  19
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Good business was often done with New Zealand hemp, the world's best fibre for binder-twine. It belongs to the lily family and is popularly termed `flax'.
 Notes:  

 Date:  14/10/1933  
 Source:  Press, The
 Author:  15
 Vol / Page:  
 Edition:  
 Quote:  <i>Flax</i>: Phormium Tenax. `The poor man's friend.' This plant, shaped like a giant tussock, was one of the most useful things that grew. The leaves or `blades' were ready-made straps and ropes for almost any purpose. The bush makes an excellent dog-kennel, and many a man has made a comfortable camp under one on a rough night. It is handy to tie a horse to and very good shelter for shorn sheep. The leaves are easily skinned; and the fibre was used for making crackers for stock and bullock whips. The individual plants are called <i>flax bushes</i> and the dried reed stalks (which Maoris and children tied into bundles to make rafts) are  called <i>flax-sticks, koradi</i> ss. o[r] <i>kraddy</i> ss., I suppose a  corrupted Maori word. On native country <i>flax</i> is always a sign of good land. ([1857 Paul Letters from Canterbury], p.96; [1898 Morris Austral-English])
 Notes:  Acland Glossary

 Date:  0/0/1936  
 Source:  Agricultural Organization in NZ
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  537
 Edition:  
 Quote:  New Zealand hemp, or `flax' as it is termed locally, is one of the so-called `hard' or leaf fibres, as contrasted with the `soft' fibres from the bast of stems.  


 Notes:

 Date:  0/0/1966

 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1973  
 Source:  Brown Man's Burden
 Author:  FINLAYSON
 Vol / Page:  140
 Edition:  
 Quote:  flax: New Zealand flax, phormium tenax, a plant that grows in clumps of tall sword-like leaves with strong fibres. Strips of the leaves are woven to make the matting used in village churches 

and meeting-houses. The fibre had commercial use, and until the depression flax mills and flax-cutters' camps, temporary rough quarters for harvesters, would be found near swamps where the flax grew. 


 Notes:  (Pearson's Glossary)

 Date:  0/0/1982  
 Source:  Collins Concise English Dictionary
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  424
 Edition:  
 Quote:  <i>flax </i>.. 4. N.Z. a swamp plant producing a fibre that is used by Maoris for decorative work, baskets, etc.

 Vol / Page:  
 Edition:  
 Quote:  A proposal was some time since made to me ... of forming a settlement at their own expence on the northern island of New Zealand, for the purpose of collecting the flax plant of that country, and manufacturing it ... ...the projectors of the flax speculation on New Zealand still intend to prosecute their design; and ... send a party of men ... on board the brig Experiment, to New Zealand, where that vessel is to remain long enough to give them time to collect a quantity of dried flax to be sent Home for the inspection of His Majesty's Ministers ... 


 Notes:  1810 Mar 12 (Sydney) Governor Macquarie to Viscount Castlereagh in 1908 McNab Historical Records 1/297 5.

 Date:  14/6/1851  
 Source:  Lyttelton Times
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  6

 Notes:  (Torlesse's Report)

 Source:  Polynesia
 Author:  ANGAS
 Vol / Page:  156
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The `topuni,' or war mat, belongs exclusively to the man, and is only possessed by chiefs ... The `topuni' consists of a large flax cloak, into which is fastened, with every thread, a portion of dog's hair, assorted into various colours, having the exact appearance of a beautiful fur.

 Date:  0/2/1777  
 Source:  Cook's Journals
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  3/805
 Edition:  
 Quote:  (Queen Charlotte Sound) ... there is one [plant] which deserves particular notice, as the natives make their garments of it and it produces a fine silky flax superior in appearance to any thing we have and probably at least as strong. It grows everywhere near the sea and in some places a considerable way up the hills, ... [ed. fn 6 <i>Phormium colensoi</i>, obviously; not the swamp-loving <i>Phormium tenax.</i>]
 Notes:  1777 Feb Anderson's Journal in Cook Journals 3/805

 Vol / Page:  3

<i>thirty</i> tons of gumless flax per week... Thus, then, we find two very considerable offers made for the employment of the Baron de Thierry's `ungummed flax;` ... 


 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1988  
 Source:  Forest Vines to Snow Tussocks
 Author:  DAWSON
 Vol / Page:  181
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The term `flax' for the genus <i>Phormium</i>, although firmly established, is yet another inappropriate common name as <i>Phormium</i> and true linen flax  (<i>Linum</i>) have in common only the possession of useful  fibres. Mountain flax is <i>Phormium cookianum</i> and its tufts of narrow, leathery leaves may be conspicuous in poorly drained places in tussock herbfield and shrubland.

 Quote:  The soil of the plain is of various character : a considerable portion consists of a light dry vegetable soil, well adapted for clover paddocks, or for the growth of barley; about an equal quantity is dark-coloured, good, strong flaxland, suitable for wheat and potatoes; ...


 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1868  
 Source:  Contributions to NZ Botany
 Author:  LINDSAY
 Vol / Page:  80
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Hence, next to bush and swamp-land proper (on alluvial clays), Flax-land is regarded as the most desirable for agricultural purposes. `Flax-swamps' are frequently as common as `Tussock-swamps,' though their soil is far from being so wet or watery. Like the `Tussock-swamps,' they are frequently very `tussocky' - causing walking thereon to be extremely ... fatiguing.
 Notes:  [cf Bush-land]

 Date:  0/0/1900  
 Source:  Canterbury Old & New
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  179
 Edition:  
 Quote:   ... tall flax-lily (phormium tenax)....  the vegetation may be observed in thickets of tea-tree 

[fn Leptospermum], gigantic clumps of the tall flax-lily  [fn <i>Phormium tenax </i>] ... and that curious sedge known popularly as nigger-head  [fn <i>Carex vergata</i>] ... <i>Ibid.</i> 183 ... here and there the monotony is relieved by clumps of native flax-lily  [fn <i>Phormium tenax </i>.] with their broad sword-shaped leaves and tall flower-stalks, while the tall-stemmed palm-lilies  [fn <i>Cordyline australis</i>.] in places lend an almost tropical aspect to the scene.

 Date:  0/0/1973

 Vol / Page:  140
 Edition:  
 Quote:   flax: New Zealand flax, phormium tenax, a plant that grows in clumps of tall sword-like leaves with strong fibres. Strips of the leaves are woven to make the matting used in village churches

and meeting-houses. The fibre had commercial use, and until the depression flax mills and flax-cutters' camps, temporary rough quarters for harvesters, would be found near swamps where the flax grew.
 Notes:  (Pearson's Glossary)

 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  1/320
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Mr. Simmonds suggests that the marsh-tit would help in the eradication of the flax-grub. But ... the caterpillar of <I>Persectania steropastis</I> (the species which does most of the damage in the South) hides during the day in the sheaths at the bases of the leaves, where no bird could capture it. I believe that the larva of the <I>Xanthorhoe praefectata</I>, the northern flax-moth, also conceals itself during the day.

 Date:  0/0/1868  
 Source:  Contributions to NZ Botany
 Author:  LINDSAY
 Vol / Page:  80
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Hence, next to bush and swamp-land proper (on alluvial clays), Flax-land is regarded as the most desirable for agricultural purposes. `Flax-swamps' are frequently as common as `Tussock-swamps,' though their soil is far from being so wet or watery. Like the `Tussock-swamps,' they are frequently very `tussocky' - causing walking thereon to be extremely ... fatiguing.
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1870  
 Source:  TrNZI
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  2/117
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The Korari is the  name of the flower stalk, often, but wrongly, used as the name of the plant. The edible root is the Aruhe. The word `Muka' is commonly applied to the dressed fibre; it is the correct name for the inner leaves. Cleared bush-land is suitable for the cultivation of the flax plant, and even swamp-land is improved by drainage. In the various flax

swamps near nelson ...the finest plants grow upon the soil that has been thrown out of the ditch ... 


 Notes:  (Heaphy NZ Flax)

 Date:  0/0/1973  
 Source:  Brown Man's Burden
 Author:  FINLAYSON
 Vol / Page:  140
 Edition:  
 Quote:  flax: New Zealand flax, phormium tenax, a plant that grows in clumps of tall sword-like leaves with strong fibres. Strips of the leaves are woven to make the matting used in village churches 

and meeting-houses. The fibre had commercial use, and until the depression flax mills and flax-cutters' camps, temporary rough quarters for harvesters, would be found near swamps where the flax grew.
 Notes:  (Pearson's Glossary)

The fibre was not strong enough to lift the large eel out of the water.

 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1918  
 Source:  NZ Journal of Science & Technology
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  1/132
 Edition:  
 Quote:  ... the marsh tit of Europe would doubtless help considerably in the control of the flax-grub which is at present causing heavy losses to the country. <i>Ibid.</> 1/320  Mr. Simmonds suggests that the marsh-tit would help in the eradication of the flax-grub. But ... the caterpillar of <I>Persectania steropastis</I> (the species which does most of the damage in the South) hides during the day in the sheaths at the bases of the leaves, where no bird could capture it. I believe that the larva  of the <I>Xanthorhoe praefectata</I>, the northern flax-moth, also conceals itself during the day.

 Quote:  The ones attracting most attention were the owlet moths, the caterpillars of which destroyed the first pastures and cereal and root crops. There were also porina moths (<I>Oxycanus</I> spp.) whose caterpillars also destroyed pastures; the bag moth (<I>Oeceticus omnivorus</I>) which left cigar-shaped cocoons hanging from shrubs and tree [sic]; and the ghost-like white moth ... of the flax grub (<I>Orthoclydon praefectata</I>) which eats longitudinal slits on the surface of [flax] leaves ...

 flax-house
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: 
 Origin: 
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
 Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1840  
 Source:  Manners & Customs of the NZers
 Author:  POLACK
 Vol / Page:  1/185
 Edition:  
 Quote:  and a flax-house at [186] Uwoua, eighty feet long by twenty-four broad and forty feet high to the

ridge-pole, was built by a chief and a large company of natives for a small keg of powder 25lbs. in weight. The house was extremely water-tight and warm, and several streams and marshes had been denuded of their rushes (raupo) to cover the roof and sides; ... <I>Ibid. 1/210-211 The largest public works undertaken are those of flax-houses, some of which are above one hundred [211] feet in length, thirty feet in width, and forty feet in height. These are built less for ornament than being durable and water-tight, as any rain pouring on the flax would discolour and finally rot it.

 Edition:  
 Quote:  ... the service was European fashion. We sat at a table with a white cloth, forks and spoons. I felt a lingering longing for the old hospitality of former days, when the company sat on the ground, upon clean flax mats spread over the floor, when each guest had a separate portion

handed to him by a Maori girl in a little green flax kit, woven for the occasion, potatoes and meat and vegetable marrow together, to which he had to help himself with his fingers.

 flax-stick

 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number:  1
 Definition:  a dry flower stem of Phormium tenax, used by Maori and early European settlers for fences, raft-making and fire building.

 Date:  0/0/1981  
 Source:  Weeds of Roadsides
 Author:  TAYLOR
 Vol / Page:  55
 Edition:  
 Quote:  BROAD-LEAVED FLEABANE (<I>Erigeron floribundus</I>). ... Introduced from South America, this species ... is by far the commonest fleabane in  New Zealand. ... <I>Canadian fleabane (Erigeron canadensis)</I> ... introduced from North America, is common in some districts from Christmas northwards. ... <I>wavy-leaved fleabane (Erigeron bonariensis)</I>. ... This South America plant is common in a few New Zealand towns on footpaths and vacant sections.

 Source:  Press, The
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  15
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Fleece: (1) The whole of a sheep's wool. (Canterbury Rhymes) (2) The main part of a sheep's wool, which is picked up in one, skirted  and rolled. This is sold as fleece wool, as opposed to

locks,  bellies and pieces. (C.)
 Notes:  Acland Glossary

 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1987  
 Source:  Boards, Blades & Barebellies
 Author:  OGONOWSKA-COATES
 Vol / Page:  96
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Fleece. The main part of the sheep's wool when shorn. It is picked up in one piece and carried to the wool table, where it is skirted and classed. The small bits and pieces that are cut off separately by the shearer are the locks, bellies and pieces.

 Vol / Page:  3/24
 Edition:  
 Quote:  fleece: On the sheep the fleece is all the wool, but once shorn it does not have the `belly wool' and other locks which are packed separately.

 Date:  0/0/1913  
 Source:  Country Work
 Author:  CARR
 Vol / Page:  15
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Wool Rolling. - When the fleece is thrown on the table by the fleece-picker, the wool rollers (generally there are two) skirt - i.e., take off the dirty wool - the neck (in some sheds) and legs, ... turn in the sides and roll up, from each end. The Classer, by feel, sight, and general knowledge, decides what class it belongs to.
 Notes:

 Quote:  Fleece-picking. - As soon as a shearer has taken the fleece off and let the sheep go through the port-hole to the counting-out pen, the picker gathers the fleece up in such a manner that she or he can on getting to the rolling table, throw it out with the breech part at the right end.

 Source:  In the Land of the Tui
 Author:  WILSON
 Vol / Page:  244
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Meanwhile the shorn fleeces are carried to a large table in the wool-shed by a man appropriately named `Fleecy', and are spread out by four wool-pickers, who tear away the bad parts and fold the fleeces square, passing them to the classer, who, in turn, after a rapid examination hands them on to his attendant, and he places them in their respective bins according to their quality.

 fleet up
 Homonym Number:

 Date:  0/0/1998  
 Source:  On the Next Tide
 Author:  HARGREAVES
 Vol / Page:  42
 Edition:  
 Quote:  When you've got a heap of mud in a trawl, you can't get the whole net in because of the weight, so you've got to put a strop round it, lift a bit up, empty that, then put another strop on, and get that bit out, and so on. It's called fleeting up, and you've got to do that about five times to get it all on board.
 Notes:

 fleshing
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: 
 Origin: 
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation:

 Citations 
 Date:  0/8/1921  
 Source:  NZ Journal of Science & Technology
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  4/159
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The process of fleshing is usually carried out by machines operating a right-and-left spiral knife-cylinder ... flesh side to the knife cylinder. A process similar to fleshing is also carried out in order to remove as much as possible of the hair root-sheaths and fat glands upon the grain side of the pelt. This process is known as `scudding', the skins being fed into the machine, grain side to the knife cylinder.
 Notes:  (Wright)

 Date:  15/9/1950  
 Source:  NZ Journal of Agriculture
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  258

 Quote:  Here the hide is fleshed or flayed by hand to remove any surplus fat and meat left on in butchering ... These fleshings are sent to the tallow department ...

 Quote:  Contrary to what the name suggested, "flex beds" were not a new tool for physiotherapists, but the "converse to resource beds". Eh? That is beds occasionally "flexed" into use, versus those always available for use.

our island coast line... In calm autumn days often have we watched the still waters of our shallow bays flash with the swift motion of the flip-flap.

 flipping
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number:  1
 Definition: the breaking up of hard soil pans by bringing the underlying free-draining soils from 1 metre below ground to the surface. 


 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: Rural
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
 Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  31/5/2002  
 Source:  Personal Communication
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  
 Edition:  
 Quote:  I have recently done a small amount of work with Agriculture NZ and some of the dairy farmers in the Cape Foulwind area looking at the changes in soils from flipping.
 Notes:  pc with Dr Craig Ross, Landcare Research:

 Date:  25/10/2001  
 Source:  Taranaki Daily News
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  19
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The most innovative soil improvement technique to be used in the conversions will be pasture flipping - a practice pioneered at Cape Foulwind to bring free-draining soils to the surface and turn sour wetland into lush pasture .. A group of Cape Foulwind dairy farmers, together with Agriculture New Zealand consultant Richard Reynolds, and Landcare Research Scientist Dr Craig Ross, are evaluating flipping or breaking up the pakihi iron pan to bring free-draining soil to the top. The technique was developed by a local farmer, the late Fred King, and his son Alex, and costs between $2500 and $5000 a hectare.
 Notes:

 flock
 Homonym Number:  1
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: (of sheep) as a collective for the total sheep of a farm etc. -->1981 the official name for a group of two or more sheep with a single owner. (flock to be distinguished from mob - a number of sheep running together.)

 Date:  21/10/1933  
 Source:  Press, The
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  15
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Flock: (1) The whole of the sheep on a farm or station; (2) the whole of the ewes or wethers on a station are sometimes spoken of as the ewe or wether flock. A number of sheep running together are a  mob (q.v.). `Such a large flock as this - about 50,000.'

 Vol / Page:  32
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Flock: the total of an owner's sheep. It may also mean the total of his sheep of any particular breed or any kind. eg Corriedale--, ewe--, or wether flock. Townspeople may incorrectly term a mob they see being driven along the road as a 'flock.'

 Vol / Page:  10/321
 Edition:  
 Quote:  So, too, the wild dog (Canis familiaris) is now unknown. For some years after the settlers arrived here the wild dog was the terror of the flockmaster ... But the bulk of the wild dogs were not domestic animals gone wild, but the true old Maori wild dog. I know that this statement will be questioned by many who have never believed that there were genuine old-identity wild dogs in New Zealand before Europeans ...
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1947  
 Source:  Early Runholding in Otago
 Author:  BEATTIE
 Vol / Page:  11
 Edition:  
 Quote:  When I first read this inscription [in the Memorial Church, Cave], the word `sheep-men' made me involuntarily flinch. Years later, when I had forgotten it, I suddenly met it again, and again I recoiled. So aghast was I that I spent weeks collecting every old term for `runholders' I could, and I found thirteen, viz., `flock owners,' `flock masters,' `pastoralists,' `run holders,' `run owners,' `sheep owners,' `sheep holders,' `sheep masters,' `squatters,' `station holders,' `station owners,' `stock holders,[sic] and `stock owners.'  The word `sheepmen' is a modern Americanism, and

using this anachronism mars a splendid memorial. ... [12] Of all the thirteen terms found in old documents, the word `runholder' was the most used, and it is the word that I think should be substituted.
 Notes:

 floodgate
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number:  1
 Definition: a heavy cable strung across a creek or river bed from which is hung a series of battens [to prevent stock moving from one paddock to another.] 


 Origin: [none]

 Edition:  
 Quote:  flood gate: Device used on a fence line where it crosses a dry watercourse. It hangs in the hollow and is so built that it can float when water rises and recede back to the bed when the flow ceases.

 flounder
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: any of various flatfish with a large mouth and both eyes usually occurring on the left side of the head; aka patiki
 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
 Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1840  
 Source:  Manners & Customs of the NZers
 Author:  POLACK
 Vol / Page:  1/202 fn
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Among  the piscivorous tribes, are those well known in Europe under the appellations of snapper, tench, haddocks, pollock, salmon, gurnets, john dory, hakes, bream, sword-fish, elephant-fish, diodons, pipe-fish, cod, parrot-fish, flounders, skate, cat and dog-fish, sting-rays,

eels. - Among the larger tribes that sport in shoals in the vicinity of the shore, are, sperm-whales, called  <i>para</i>[as-acute] <i>paraua</i>[a3-acute] (physeter macrocephalus); black whale, <i>mungu nui</i> (black physeter); right whale, <i>tohora</i> (balaena mysticetus); finback, (balaena physalis); sun-fish (diodon mola); large-lipped whale (balaena mysticetus); large-lipped whale (balaena musculus);

hump-back (balaena gibbosa); shark,  <i>mango</I> (squalus); hammer-head (zygaena); pilots, (scomber); flying-fish (exocaetus volitans); and an infinity of others, besides a great variety of testaceous and crustaceous fishes that almost cover the rocks under water, such as clams, muscles, oysters, crays, cuttles, limpets, wilks, gigantic muscles, a foot in length, cockles, sea-ears, sea-eggs, star-fish, mutton-fish, &c.; from the latter the pearl is procured which they insert in the eyes of their carved images and boxes.
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1967  
 Source:  Cook's Journals
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:   3/807
 Edition:  
 Quote:  (Queen Charlotte Sound) We observ'd already that the principal fish caught by the seyne were

Mullets [ed. fn Aldrichetta forsteri.] and Elephant fish [ed. fn  Callarhyncus milli.] & a few soles [ed. fn  Peltorhamphus novaeseelandiae.] and flounders, [ed.fn Rhombosalea spp.] but those which the Indians mostly supply'd us with are a sort of sea Bream of a silver colour with a black spot on the neck, [ed. fn Tarakihi, ...] ...
 Notes:  1777 Feb Anderson's Journal in Cook Journals  (1967) 3/807

 Vol / Page:  148
 Edition:  
 Quote:  ~ The Flounders in Australia are - In Sydney, <i>Pseudorhombus  russeli</I>, Gray; in Melbourne, <i>Rhombosolea vistoria</i>, Castln.;  in New Zealand and Tasmania, <i>R. monopus</i>, Gunth. Maori name,  Patiki; family Pleuronectida. They are all excellent eating.

 Author:  HAMILTON
 Vol / Page:  64
 Edition:  
 Quote:  ... with the following results: 581 eels (from 1ft. to 4ft. in length); 8 dozen flounders, of various sizes, large numbers of aua, or kataka (mullet); about 70lb. or 70lb. weight of pilchard, or mohimohi; a few snapper and kahawai; hundreds of red cod and rarii; and a number of kokopu

or rawaru.
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1927  
 Source:  Natural History of Canterbury
 Author:  SPEIGHT
 Vol / Page:  201
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The  four species of <i>Rhombosolea</i> are distinguished by form and colour. The best known is the Sand flounder, or simply Flounder, (<i>R. plebeia</i>) (Plate II. fig. 2) wider across than the other, while the Greenback (<i>R. tapirina</i>) with white undersurface, the Yellowbelly (<i>R. leporina</i>) and the Black flounder (<i>R. retiaria</i>) have their distinguishing colours recorded in their common names.
 Notes:  1927 Archey `Native Fishes of Canterbury' in  Speight et al. Natural History of Canterbury 201 



 Date:  0/0/1970  
 Source:  Nomenclature of NZ Fish
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  24
 Edition:  
 Quote:  FLOUNDER (four species) (a) Scientific name: (i)<I> Rhombosolea plebeia</I> (ii)<I> Rhombosolea retiaria</i> (iii) <i>Rhombosolea tapirina</i> (iv) <i>Rhombosolea leporina</i>. (b) Suggested commercial name[s]: (i) Flounder (ii) Freshwater Flounder (iii) Flounder (iv) Yellowbelly Flounder. (c) Other common names: (i) Square, Dab, Plaice, Diamond or Diamond-back, Tin-plate, Three Corners. (ii) Blacks, Black Flounder (iii) Greenback [25 `Not common but occasionally taken in southern

waters.'] (iv) Yellow Flounder.

 floured mercury
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: 
 Origin: [none]
 Register:

 See:

 Source:  West Coast Gold Rushes
 Author:  MAY
 Vol / Page:  527
 Edition:  1962
 Quote:  FLOURED MERCURY: mercury that has lost its amalgamating properties because of impurities in the ore or the wash. The mercury is then `sick'. 


 Notes:  

 flouring
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: 
 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
 Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1876  
 Source:  TrNZI
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  8/334
 Edition:  
 Quote:  While on an official visit to the Thames Goldfield I ...[observed] the ... effect of Cyanide of Potassium, in preventing the flouring of mercury used in working the blanketings. These blanketings I found have ... a decidedly acid reaction, due ... to the presence of ferric and ferrous salts ..., and it is to the former ... that what is commonly known as [335] `flouring,' is mainly due, in the process cited above; such ferric salts being able to either oxidize or chloridize the surface of any mercury ..., thus enfilming it with a compound, which being practically insoluble in water ... prevents that metallic contact taking place between detached mercurial globules, which is necessary to amalgamation. 


 Notes:  (Skey)

 Sense Number: 
 Definition: an artificial water channel for industrial use or for carrying logs. [Latin flumen a river]
 Origin: 
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]

 Date:  0/0/1871  
 Source:  Knocking About in NZ
 Author:  MONEY
 Vol / Page:  15
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Our object was to make a `flume', or aqueduct, which should carry the water of the creek above our heads, and allow us to work in the bed of it below. 


 Notes:  

 Date:  30/1/1873  
 Source:  Diary
 Author:  G.M.WILSON
 Vol / Page:  
 Edition:  
 Quote:  A good breakfast, and off we start on our tramp. ... On the hill side sometimes as high as 1000 feet up, we see numerous races or flumes as they are called used by diggers to take water to sluice the gold out of the stuff the gold is found in.
 Notes:  1873 Jan 30 G.M.Wilson Diary in 1973 Wierzbicka Wilson Family 158

 Date:  0/0/1879  
 Source:  Australian Abroad, The
 Author:  HINGSTON
 Vol / Page:  293
 Edition:  
 Quote:  At these [West Coast] diggings ... we could not but notice the use made of flumes - long gutters of wood, supported on sticks twenty feet or more in height, bringing and taking away water for dozens and dozens of miles.
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1935  
 Source:  Gold Mining Year Book
 Author:  BLYTH
 Vol / Page:  11
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Flume: Boxing or piping used to convey water from higher ground to a lower level. Some companies, working on River Claims ...
 Notes:  (Glossary)

 Date:  0/0/1967  
 Source:  West Coast Gold Rushes
 Author:  MAY
 Vol / Page:  527
 Edition:  1962
 Quote:  FLUMES: the more artificial portion of a water-race, consisting of piping, hose or wooden boxes; most commonly applied to wooden boxes used for conveying water to the claim. 


 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1978  
 Source:  Gold Mining at Waihi (Glossary)
 Author:  McARA
 Vol / Page:  322
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Flume: An aqueduct. Several of these were used to carry water-races over streams and gullies. 

There were two large arch-supported flumes across the Ohinemuri River carrying the 12 ft by 4 ft low-pressure race.

opening [175] through the dam, the sides and floor of which were four-inch planking.

 Edition:

 Date:  0/0/1972  
 Source:  Folkgames of Children
 Author:  SUTTON-SMITH
 Vol / Page:  175
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Some of the typical terms used in marbles referred to the act of shooting and the movement of  the marbles. Those related to ways of shooting marbles were cribbing, firsts, fudging, funks, funnicks, funnigans, flunks, forces, knee-high, knuckle-down-stiff, knuckles, and lasts. Terms connected with the movement of the marbles were: cannons, clears, dead-stick, double-hits, fires, funs, gees, haystacks, in smug, keeps, kills, kisses, lay-ups, manyes, ones, pink, ringer, rolls, scat, screws, skinned, skun, spiders, sported-off, stays, stops, tracks, throughs.

 Notes:  

 Date:  17/5/1951  
 Source:  Personal Communication
 Author:  COLIN GORDON
 Vol / Page:  
 Edition:  
 Quote:   This is a seasonal job and gives rise to phrases like: `Chaps winter at a certain job (e.g. shearing) in the off-season, and come back regularly. The season is divided into the flush when lambs are coming in (two flushes `grass-fed' and `rape-fed'). After the first flush of

lambs, a lot of sheep come in,  wo-olly iwis [wou li: |i:wi:z] as they are called. they are tougher than lambs and the tally is therefore less - 80 instead of 100 say; and they are often called  grannies or grandmother lambs.
 Notes:  Feilding Freezing Works terms

 Date:  17/11/1937  
 Source:  King Country Chronicle

 Vol / Page:  5

 Quote:  The November "flush" has failed to materialise at the Te Kuiti cream dumps.

 fly
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: `the flap at the entrance of a tent' (O.E.D.), most commonly, as part of the tent or as a separate but attachable unit.  Fly `canopy' as Satchell has it looks wrong but is nonetheless legitimate according to Auckland's senior firm of tentmakers, which  kindly answered enquiries about this. Fly `shelter piece' appears at p. 43, as `a small fly of palm leaves'.

 Date:  2/3/2002  
 Source:  Listener (New Zealand Listener)
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  9
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Charles Lush, of Parnell, Auckland, on January 22, 1864, wrote in his diary about his activities that day, including, "... I also bought two penny worth of fly kooks for Martin." Alison Drummond, the editor of the <i>Waikato Journals of Vicesimus Lush</i> (Pegasus Press, 1982) in which this entry is printed, identifies "fly kooks" as "cookies, know to generations of children as 'squashed fly biscuits'"

 fly boy
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: 
 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
 Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1913  
 Source:  Country Work
 Author:  CARR
 Vol / Page:  43
 Edition:  
 Quote:  When the flax arrives at the mill it is weighed and credited to the cutter. The `bench loader' then takes two or three bundles and puts them in a barrel (heavy end down). He then takes the longest leaves and places them on a bench convenient to the `feeder'. ...[44] The `feeder' takes each blade separately and places the butt end into the `stripper' which takes the green outer covering off. ... The fibre as it leaves the stripper is caught by the `fly boy', who collects enough to make into a hank, which he places convenient for the `shaker'. The latter, with a motion like cracking a whip, gets rid of as much rubbish as possible, after which he places the hank handy for the `washer'. This man places the fibre in a vat, through which ... clean water is running.
 Notes:

 Date:  0/0/1939  
 Source:  First White Boy Born in Otago
 Author:  BEATTIE
 Vol / Page:  170
 Edition:  
 Quote:  It appeared that from October to Christmas he had made [pounds]2000 and he was now engaged in `blowing it in'. He was reeling down the street ...and when he saw me he called out, `Hey, Tom, I'm flyblown just now but come with me in a day or two and I will make your fortune for you.' [171] ... You ask what the term `flyblown' meant. It was a word used in those days [c1860s] and meant a man had no money, but once I saw a man really flyblown.

 Notes:  

 flycatcher
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: gen. English for a bird that catches flies.  In NZ earlier occas. applied (perhaps generically) to Rhipidura sp.,  fantail, probably as a now obs shortening of the semi-popular  fantailed-flycatcher.  


 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
 Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  2/4/1773  
 Source:  Resolution Journal of J.R. Forster, The
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  2/245
 Edition:  
 Quote:  In the morning ... Huia. The Zosterops was everywhere abundant, also the Grey Warbler and Rifleman, and ... we found the Tomtit comparatively plentiful; the Parakeet chased its mate through the tree-tops with sharp cries of `twenty-eight'; ... and among the tangle of the underwood the ever-present 

Flycatcher displayed its pretty fan-like tail.

 flycatcher

 Sense Number: 2

 Date:  0/0/1881  
 Source:  TrNZI
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  13/261
 Edition:  
 Quote:  All our species [of Drosera] catch and digest insects, and in fact are known in some districts by the name of `Fly-catchers'. <i>Ibid.</i> 325  (Petrie) Insects are so frequently caught in the glandular hairs of [Drosera spp] leaves that these herbs are known among the observant Southland settlers as `fly-catchers'.  [also 1881 ibid 13/261 (Thomson)] 


 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1889  
 Source:  Art Album NZ Flora
 Author:  FEATON
 Vol / Page:  141
 Edition:  
 Quote:  DROSERA. (Linn.) The Sundew ... one can scarcely examine a plant without finding the wings and legs of insects, on one or more of the leaves. ... This extremely interesting genus is represented in New Zealand by six species, all of which are said to digest meats, and are known to [142] the settlers as `Fly-catchers'.

 Vol / Page:  74
 Edition:  1967
 Quote:  CATCHFLY (<i>Silene [gallica]</i>). Varieties of this species have  been named<i> S.anglica</i> and <i>S. quinque vulnera</I>.  [1967 quinquevulnera] Common names are spotted catchfly, flycatcher, sticky weed, and five wounds. It is common in cultivated land and waste places such as gravelly river-beds throughout both islands. ... The flowers are white or often dark red, or sometimes white with a blood red  blotch on each petal so that this variety is called <i>quinque vulnera</i>, `five wounds'.

 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1840  
 Source:  Manners & Customs of the NZers
 Author:  POLACK
 Vol / Page:  1/202fn
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Among the piscivorous tribes, are those well known in Europe under the appellations of snapper, tench, haddocks, pollock, salmon, gurnets, john dory, hakes, bream, sword-fish, elephant-fish, diodons, pipe-fish, cod, parrot-fish, flounders, skate, cat and dog-fish, sting-rays, eels. - Among the larger tribes that sport in shoals in the vicinity of the shore, are, sperm-whales, called  <i>para</i>[as-acute] <i>paraua</i>[a3-acute] (physeter macrocephalus); black whale, <i>mungu nui</i> (black physeter); right whale, <i>tohora</i> (balaena mysticetus); finback, (balaena physalis); sun-fish (diodon mola); large-lipped whale (balaena mysticetus); large-lipped whale (balaena musculus); hump-back (balaena gibbosa); shark, <i>mango</i> (squalus); hammer-head (zygaena); pilots, (scomber); flying-fish (exocaetus volitans); and an infinity of others, besides a great variety of testaceous and crustaceous fishes that almost cover the rocks under water, such as clams, muscles, oysters, crays, cuttles, 
limpets, wilks, gigantic muscles, a foot in length, cockles, sea-ears, sea-eggs, star-fish, mutton-fish, &c.; from the latter the pearl is procured which they insert in the eyes of their carved images and boxes.

 flying gurnard
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: 
 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
 Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1898  
 Source:  Austral English
 Author:  MORRIS
 Vol / Page:  
 Edition:  
 Quote:  <i>Gurnet ... [Gurnard </i>cross-referenced to <i>Gurnet</i>]  The species of <i>Trigla</i> found in British waters, called <i>Gurnards</i> are of the family of <i>Cottidae</i>. The word <i>Gurnet</i> is an obsolete or provincial form of <i>Gurnard</i>, revived in Australia, and  applied to the fish <i>Centropogon scorpaenoides</i>, Guich., family Scorpaenidae. The original word <i>Gurnard</i> is retained in New Zealand, and applied to the new species <i>Trigla kumu</i> (kumu being the Maori name), family Cottidae. The <i>Flying Gurnet</i> is 

<i>Trigla polyommata</i>, Richards., found on all the Australian coasts  from New South Wales to Western Australia, family <i>Cottidae</i>. It is a distinct species, not included in the British species. They have large pectoral fins, but are not known to possess the power of supporting themselves in the air like the `flying fish' which belong  to other genera. Sir Fredk. McCoy says that <i>Sebastes Percoides</i>,  Richards., is called Gurnet, or Garnet-perch, by the fishermen and dealers, as well as the more common <i>Neosebastes scorpaenoides</i>,  Guich., and <i>Scorpaena panda</i>, Richards.] <i>Ibid.</i> 384 

<i>Red Gurnet-Perch, n.</i> name given in Victoria to the fish <i>Sebastes percoides</i>,  Richards., family <i>Scorpeaenidae</i>. It is also called <i>Poddy; Red Gurnard</i>, or <i>Gurnet</i>; and in New Zealand, <i>Pohuikaroa</i>.  See <i>Perch</i> and <i>Gurnet</i>.]
 Notes:  

 Date:  15/1/1770  
 Source:  Journal
 Author:  PARKINSON
 Vol / Page:  114
 Edition:  
 Quote:  All the coves of this bay teem with fish of various kinds, such as cuttle-fish, large breams, ... small grey breams, small and large barracootas, flying gurnards, horse-mackarel, dog-fish, soles, dabs, mullets, drums, scorpenas or rock-fish, cole-fish, the beautiful fish called chimera, and

shags. [In the Stout Collection copy, Victoria University Library, an early 19th C. or late 18th C. hand has added: `*Baracootas, a fish remarkably smooth about 7 or 8 foot long [dagger] Flying Gurnards, a flying fish, of a remarkable fine Gold Colour. [double dagger] Chimeras, a fish of Silver Colour - [triple dagger] Drum fish, so call'd from the noise they make, - '  -

 Author:  GORDON
 Vol / Page:  164
 Edition:  
 Quote:  A recent invention can, however, save a lot of bleary eyes and night shifts - the foaling alarm. It's a battery-powered transmitter that's fixed to a collar round the mare's neck so that when she lies down to foal, it triggers an alarm beside Nick's bed. The alarm not only eliminates night staff, but puts a lot less stress on the mare.

 follows
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: 
 Origin: 
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
 Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1972  
 Source:  Folkgames of Children
 Author:  SUTTON-SMITH
 Vol / Page:  174
 Edition:  
 Quote:  In the nineteenth century the ring game seems to have been the most popular marble game. (In more recent years marble games with holes have had the greater role.) There was Big Ring, in which a circle a yard or more in diameter was drawn on the ground; there was the mullibar variation, in which an outsize taw was catapulted amongst the marbles in this circle. There were

Little Ring, Liney, Follows, Follow the Taw, Holey, and then, on a less important scale, Butcher's Board, in which the marbles were bowled through the holes in a board, Eye-Drop, Knock-Backs, Leggings-Out (or Leggin's-Out), Span-'Em, and Backits. The last was more usually a girls' game.
 Notes:

 foot
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number:  1
 Definition: [fencing] a piece of wood or other solid material buried at the foot of a post to ensure that it remains vertical. 


 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: Rural
 Region: [none]

 foot
 Homonym Number:  1
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: a block of wood attached by wire to a post and buried with the post in the posthole; or some other device to stop the post being pulled out when the fence is strained

 Region: [none]

 Vol / Page:  
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Northland Posts in a dip are called `foot-posts' because they require `footing' to prevent their lifting as wires are strained. A `foot' is a buried block of wood fastened either to the post or to the wires.

An apology induced the Magistrate to dismiss the defendant wth a caution, and a reminder that the streets of Wellington were not now so unfrequented that the ancient practice could be continued with impunity.

 Source:  Land Girls, The
 Author:  BARDSLEY
 Vol / Page:  148
 Edition:  
 Quote:  I killed sheep, did the dagging, footrotted sheep and branded cattle.
 Notes:  

 foot-rot
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number:  1
 Definition:  a disease of sheep's feet caused by a micro-organism Fuciformis nodosus, and often Spirochaeta penortha, resulting in lameness, and eventual starvation. 


 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: Rural
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
 Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1959  
 Source:  NZ Farmers' Veterinary Guide
 Author:  EDGAR
 Vol / Page:  108
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Foot rot is a very common infection of sheep's feet, with as much as 30 per cent of a flock affected at a time. Two bacteria, Dichelobacter nodosus and Fusobacterium necrophorum, operating together cause foot rot.
 Notes:  

 Date:  30/11/1867  
 Source:  Weekly News
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  18
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Romney Marsh are perhaps engaging more attention ... not liable to take foot-rot on the dampest bottoms.
 Notes:  

 Date:  15/7/1940  
 Source:  NZ Journal of Agriculture
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  4
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Foot-rot is a disease which has become exceedingly common and may cause considerable financial loss.
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1958  
 Source:  Sheep.  Part 1, Sheep husbandry
 Author:  STEVENS
 Vol / Page:  119
 Edition:  
 Quote:  If any cases of foot-rot are found, the whole bought-in mob should be kept in isolation for a period sufficiently long to ensure that all have sound, uninfected feet. Not until the hill-country breeding farms eradicate foot-rot will its complete control on fat-lamb farms become a practical possibility.
 Notes:  

 foot-rot
 Homonym Number:

 Sense Number:

 foot-rot trough
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number:  1
 Definition: a foot bath in which sheep are treated with bluestone or a proprietary product against foot-rot.

money, so I went to the milkbar and bought a gobstopper and some other lollies. I stuffed my face, and felt crook all the way home. He bought new footy boots for my eldest brother too, and an Art Union ticket for Mum. He must have had a beaut time up the RSA that day, I reckon.

 force
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: the power of dogs to move sheep
 Origin: 
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
 Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  21/10/1933  
 Source:  Press, The
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  15
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Force.. It is different from eye, the dog's control of sheep by staring them in the face, and from noise, in that there are plenty of dogs which yap, yap continually and yet seem to make little or no impression on their sheep. Huntaways are sometimes spoken of as forcing dogs; but the term force is also applied to the ability of a heading dog to pull sheep. (C.) 


 Notes:  Acland Glossary

 forces
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: 
 Origin: 
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
 Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1953  
 Source:  Unorganized Games
 Author:  SUTTON-SMITH
 Vol / Page:  2/769
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Action terms which refer to the shooting of the marbles are: Knuckle down Stiff, Knee High, Funks [Flunks sic] or Funnicks, Slips, Firsts and Lasts and Forces. ... The term `Knuckle down 

Stiff' (Taranaki [18]80, Gisborne [18]85, Waitara [18]95) is mentioned by [Lady A.B. Gomme Vo. 1, p.113]. ... As Taranaki [18]80 says, `The term was called out in order to prevent too easy a success against a marble near the ring'. It was less advantageous to fire with the hand on the ground than with the hand elevated, perhaps at `Knee High'. 


 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1972  
 Source:  Folkgames of Children
 Author:  SUTTON-SMITH
 Vol / Page:  175
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Some of the typical terms used in marbles referred to the act of shooting and the movement of the marbles. Those related to ways of shooting marbles were cribbing, firsts, fudging, funks, funnicks, funnigans, flunks, forces, knee-high, knuckle-down-stiff, knuckles, and lasts. Terms connected with the movement of the marbles were: cannons, clears, dead-stick, double-hits, fires, funs, gees, haystacks, in smug, keeps, kills, kisses, lay-ups, manyes, ones, pink, ringer, rolls, scat, screws, skinned, skun, spiders, sported-off, stays, stops, tracks, throughs. <i>Ibid.</i> 269 [marble term] Here are some [marble] terms from Taranaki around 1880-1890: firsts, lay-up, stakes, tips, sticking-taw, nothings, anythings, fade-it, knuckledown stiff, dubs, finking [sic, ?funking], sips, spanning, placing; and from Dunedin School in 1949: knee high, manyies, tracks, screws, nuts, sleets, kills, forces, dig, dubs, cheats.

 Notes:   Acland Glossary

 Date:  0/0/1955  
 Source:  Wool Away!
 Author:  BOWEN
 Vol / Page:  120
 Edition:  
 Quote:   [=CRUSH PEN] Receiving yards. These must have the capacity to take incoming 

mobs. They communicate with the forwarding yards, or diamond pens, which are much smaller, and lead up to the crush pens or forcing pens. ...  These last [crush pens or forcing pens] are usually one or two long pens that communicate by a two-way gate with the mouth of the drafting race.

 Notes:  (Firth)

 Date:  0/9/1958  
 Source:  Tararua
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  23
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Forest is, of course, still in use, but it does not come as  naturally to the tongue as bush, and there are no words derived from it in this part of the world. It is stiffer, more formal, more technical. We may speak of kauri forest or beech forest, but we get lost in the bush, fight bush fires, and climb above the bushline. The kauri forest, like the mixed podocarp forest, the sub-tropical rain forest, ... and such-like are terms that come from the botanist and forester, not from the layman - or from the bushman.
 Notes:  Ruth Mason `Track and Trail'

 Forest Accord
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: 
 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
 Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/8/2002  
 Source:  Forest & Bird
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  305/40
 Edition:  
 Quote:  On several occasions recently, private Forestry companies have consulted with Forest and Bird branches about logging access protected under the Forest Accord... The Accord was built upon the Tasman Accord, negotiated in 1988 between Forest and Bird and Tasman (now Fletcher) Forests, following lively protest against the company's clear-felling of native forest to plant pine trees. Both accords saw conservationists agree to champion sustainable pine forests, and the forestry companies agree not to plant pine trees at the expense of native forest.

 forest park
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: former name for conservation park q.v.
 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
 Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/9/1958  
 Source:  Tararua
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  30
 Edition:  
 Quote:  It may be remarked that National Park is American in origin, dating from 1872, about the time that Yosemite was set aside for recreational purposes. In England, park, like forest, may have a definite legal meaning when it applies to a tract of land held by royal grant for keeping beasts of the chase. Unlike a forest, a park is enclosed, and [31] it does not have special laws or offices. In all the uses to which park has been put in England, until the recent adoption of National Park, there has been the idea of enclosure, as there is in the cognate paddock. The term forest park, as in the Tararua Forest Park, would once have seemed a contradiction in terms.  


 Notes:  Ruth Mason `Track and Trail'

 Date:  0/0/1926  
 Source:  Weeds of New Zealand
 Author:  HILGENDORF
 Vol / Page:  143
 Edition:  1967
 Quote:  FORGET-ME-NOT (<i>Myosotis</i> spp.). - [six] species of this genus have been introduced, and are found chiefly in wet places, though some occur in cultivated fields, and <i>LM. arvensis</i> (scorpion grass) is found in dry pastures and waste places in Wellington province.

 Source:  Canterbury Old & New
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  188
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Presently we may emerge from the forest upon some moor-like tableland in the heart of the ranges, where we again meet with a characteristic flora composed largely of heath-like Gaultherias, white gentians, blue ground-lilies, yellow forget-me-nots [fn <i>Myosotis australis</i>.], native daisies [fn <i>Brachycome Sinclairii</i>.], creeping veronicas, and white-flowered Pimeleas, with magnificent clumps of the larger Spaniard.

 Author:  BULLER
 Vol / Page:  318

 Forty Thieves
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: a powerful group of (original) colonial landowners
 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
 Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1940  
 Source:  Marlborough
 Author:  McINTOSH
 Vol / Page:  137
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Though his assertions may be discounted the spirit of Saunders's utterances may be taken as a reflection of the attitude of the popular party. In commenting on the fact that the power acquired by `the Original Resident Land Purchasers' Association' was retained long after the Company had ceased to exist, Saunders states `It became a leading and bitter opponent, a dangerous and mischievous class combination, facetiously called `The Nelson Supper Party' and more viciously called also `The Forty Thieves'. This party was very ably led by Dr., afterwards Sir David, Monro, and retained all political power in their own hands until some time after the introduction of representative government into this country.
 Notes:  [Saunders in ? Nelson Examiner Oct 1857]

 Date:  0/0/1873  
 Source:  Master, The
 Author:  ROLLESTON
 Vol / Page:  96
 Edition:  1980
 Quote:  The notoriety of the defendants [at the 1873 Native Lands Alienation Commission] gave rise to their being called, variously, the twelve apostles (actually only seven were involved in the ownership of twelve shares) or the forty thieves.
 Notes:  

 Date:  6/1/1849  
 Source:  Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  
 Edition:  
 Quote:  In the outset of the Company's colonisation scheme, there were certain individuals who, by their disinterestedness in forwarding the establishment of the Company's first and principal settlement, obtained the sobriquet of the Forty Thieves ; and it appears that some individuals forming a portion of the Company's second Colony were anxious to rival the above-named gentlemen in a similar line of conduct. The one set proposed, that no individual holding less than five original land-orders in the settlement, should be eligible to a seat in their self- elected Council for the republican settlement of Britannia, well knowing at the time that none but themselves were qualified under such [a regulation, seeing that they were the holders of ten gratuitous landorders from the Company. The Nelson resident original landpurchasers, on the other hand, propose to exclude all persons who are not, like themselves, resident original purchasers, but who still originally emigrated here, and have become holders of land by purchase from them and the absentee land proprietors, and have embarked their labour and capital for various purposes, thereby promoting the welfare of the settlement, from any right to runs for cattle and sheep upon the waste lands.
 Notes: Sourced from Papers Past

 Quote:  I am no friend to the special settlement system, not being able to see much good that has come of it, that is to say, beyond what would have come of the forty-acre system alone.
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1977  
 Source:  To the Northward
 Author:  KEENE
 Vol / Page:  128
 Edition:  
 Quote:  During the 1850s large areas of Crown Land were made available under the 40-acre system, which entitled an adult immigrant on payment of his own fare from Britain, to a grant of 40 acres, plus 40 for his wife, and 20 for each member of his family aged between five and 18 years. Under the 40-acre system the immigrant gave an undertaking to remain in the province and not sell his land for a period of five years, after which time he would be given the freehold title of the land.
 Notes:

 Date:  0/0/1948  
 Source:  NZ Geographer
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  166
 Edition:  
 Quote:  A background of the haze engendered by tobacco and coal [in Buller pubs] is cards. As staple as beer is, more so is the game of `forty-fives', impossible of definition, where the five of the trump suit beats all other cards and the table gets a thumping. It accumulates all the good-natured interest and noise of which pubs are capable.
 Notes:   Pascoe `Coal from Buller'

 Date:  0/0/1948  
 Source:  Our Own Country
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  99
 Edition:  
 Quote:  In smoky little back parlours [in Westport] friendly little groups meet to play `forty-fives' with uproarious oaths and much heavy thumping of the table. For [100] the uninitiated it may be stated that in this  game the five-fingers (the five of the trump suit) beats all other cards. The trump suit order is five, jack, ace, king queen - all other suits begin with the king. Non-trump suits win high in red; low in black. Obviously the ace of diamonds is the lowest card in the pack unless diamonds are trumps, in which case it is the fourth best. The word `obviously' in the preceding sentence is a little optimistic - as the ace of hearts (the Maggy) is always the third best trump. It is credibly  reported (a) that the game is of Irish origin (b) that there  are no written rules (c) that the game can only be learned by  playing it, and (d) it is as characteristic of Westport as whitebait or coal.
 Notes:  Korero Our Own Country

 Date:  0/0/1963  
 Source:  Coal Flat
 Author:  PEARSON
 Vol / Page:  420
 Edition:  
 Quote:  [Gloss] Forty-fives: A peculiar card game played on the West Coast, imported originally from Ireland.
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1979  
 Source:  Spencer: the Gold Seeker
 Author:  CRUMPTON
 Vol / Page:  41
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The game played was called Forty-fives, and he could make neither head nor tail of the method of play. There was no money on the table, but a record of games played and won was made on a cribbage board by shifting a match about in the holes. At the conclusion of each game and [sic] a score of forty-five was reached, the losers shouted drinks for the other players, and the cards were shuffled round again. ... The fourth man stood up and excitedly thumped the table with the five of hearts. `I've been waiting for that, twenty-five - one - five, now lead and keep leading.'  Play and conversation went on in a similar strain. Dave endeavoured explain the rudiments of the game. `The sequence of the game is highest in red cards and lowest in black. The highest card in the pack is the five of whatever suit turns up, then comes the Jack, and the ace of hearts is always the third highest trump in the pack. But you'll never learn the game looking on, it's too hard to follow. They play four legs to a game 
which is called a `horse.' Jim's playing a hundred pounds a game, twenty pounds a leg, and twenty pounds at the completion of the game. Then they start again.'


 Notes:  [West Coast]

 Date:  0/0/1980

 Quote:  45's an Irish card game, scored on a cribbage board, still popular on the West Coast.

 Date:  15/7/1950  
 Source:  NZ Journal of Agriculture
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  7
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The forwarding yards or pens, which are considerably smaller and consequently are useful for dealing with small mobs of sheep, as well as their function of leading up to The crush or forcing pen(s): These are usually one or two long, small pens, frequently tapering at one end, and holding about 50 sheep. They in turn communicate by a two-way gate with the mouth of the 

Drafting race: This race is long and narrow just wide enough for the sheep to pass through in single file. Its purpose is to divide a mixed flock ... into any required number of smaller mobs, and for this purpose the race is fitted at its exit with one or more drafting gates, which guide the sheep into several
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1955  
 Source:  Wool Away!
 Author:  BOWEN
 Vol / Page:  120
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Receiving yards. These must have the capacity to take incoming mobs. They communicate with the forwarding yards, or diamond pens, which are much smaller, and lead up to the crush pens or  forcing pens.

 fossick
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: verb
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: 1. to search or hunt. 2. to search for gold in abandoned mines, etc.  fossicker/
 Origin: 
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
 Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1898  
 Source:  Austral English
 Author:  MORRIS
 Vol / Page:  152
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Fossick... intrans. to dig, but with special meanings. Derived,  like fosse, a ditch, and fossil, through French from  Lat. fossus, perfect part. of fodere, to dig. Fossicking as pres. part., or as verbal noun, is commoner than the 3 other parts of the verb. ... (1) To pick out gold. -->1952. W. H. Hall, `Practical Experiences at the Diggings in Victoria,' p. 16 : -->(2) To dig for gold on abandoned claims or in waste-heaps.  -->1865. F.H. Nixon, `Peter Perfume,' p. 59: -->(3) To search for gold generally, even by stealing. -->1861. T. McCombie, `Australian Sketches,' p. 60: -->(4) To search about for anything, to rummage. -->1870. S. Lemaitre, `Songs of Goldfilds,' p. 14:] -->A. v.t. -->1a. (goldminers') (i) to search out and find (alluvial gold) small amounts of gold

 Date:  0/0/1888  
 Source:  Antipodean Notes
 Author:  D'AVIGDOR
 Vol / Page:  169
 Edition:  
 Quote:  [Colonialisms] `To fossick about' meant, in the first instance, to search the chinks and crannies of a rocky watercourse for gold; it has now come to mean any searching at hap-hazard. This is no doubt akin to or  derived from fosse (French) and fossa (Latin).

loaf, and tea (post and rails) could be bought for 1/- per lb. Some of these contract cooks were great fossickers and managed to find quite a lot of green stuff for vegetables ...

 Author:  PINNEY
 Vol / Page:  48
 Edition:  
 Quote:  He objected to to breeding halfbreds in order to sell them all as four-tooths; while older and older Merinos were retained ...
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1987  
 Source:  Boards, Blades & Barebellies
 Author:  OGONOWSKA-COATES
 Vol / Page:  94
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Ages of sheep. Although there are many variations, the following names are usually used: A 

sheep is a lamb until weaned. After weaning a lamb  is called a hogget until shorn. A male lamb is a  ram lamb until castrated, then a wether. A female  lamb is a ewe lamb. After shearing, a ewe or ram  lamb is usually called a shorn hogget until  cutting the first two teeth. It is then called a  two-tooth. Some use the term two-tooth as soon as the lamb is shorn. Next year the sheep is a  four-tooth, then a six-tooth and then an  eight-tooth or full-mouthed sheep. It is full-mouthed as long as the teeth remain perfect but then becomes broken-mouthed and gummy. 


 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1898  
 Source:  Ann. Rep. Dept of Agriculture
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  VI/71
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The sheep forwarded to the laboratory were one "two-tooth" and one "four-tooth."

 Date:  0/0/1966

 Author:  NEWTON
 Vol / Page:  174

 Quote:  A ewe that goes to the ram as a four-tooth is exactly three years old when it has its first lamb.


 Notes:  

 Date:  3/6/1924  
 Source:  Otago Witness
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  13
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The evidence for the defence is that a four-tooth ewe ceases to be a four-tooth as soon as the fifth tooth, or the fifth and sixth tooth, appear through the gums... The witnesses for the plaintiff... are unanimous in their opinion that a ewe two and a-half years old is still a four-tooth ewe, although the fifth and sixth teeth have appeared... I have accordingly to settle the matter as follows - a ewe is correctly defined as a four-tooth until the fifth and sixth tooth reach maturity.

 Author:  SLATTER
 Vol / Page:  85
 Edition:  
 Quote:  There was [postal] work [in the 1960s], hard satisfying work. Unloading parcel bags, huge cumbersome containers nicknamed pre-fabs, from a three-door Z. There was slots, there was lumps, there was packing fragies in bottlos, there was the tying down of the north line for a clearance, the scissors, lead seals and squeezers. The sorters on call-back flicking circulars with precision. The volcanoes of letters on the facing-up table, the checker chanting the reds onto the

lorry, the checker calling the overseas in, London 45 ... The queue of men working at the parcel depot or the postal siding ... Tieing down the cargon. ... The sorters' school at the posties' pub known colloquially as Box 44 or the B.B.C., the Back Bar of the Cecil. The cheerful abuse of

cobbers.

The frameless pack of course receives that name only on formal occasions, being more familiarly known by that elegant term, <i>kidney-rotter</i>, or less frequently as<i> kidney-buster, kidney-crusher, kidney-sweater or kidney-rider. </i>

The whole was enclosed with stout calico ...

In all, 11,000 Kelso ewes are spread across six farms - the three farm franchises, farm at Taihape and Colyton that run Kelso-owned ewes and hoggets, and a farm near Marton... For now, Kelso Ltd is concentrating on helping the franchise farms consolidate their flocks.

 Vol / Page:  2

 Quote:  It is rumored - but we can't vouch for the accuracy of it - that as soon as road lines are cut through the bush country the land will be thrown open for free selection as was done in Canterbury. We are, however, disposed to receive the statement with caution, because the principle of free selection in bush country would be much more difficult to carry out than it would be in open land.

 free selector
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number:  1
 Definition: [also used in Aus.] a farmer who buys land from the government with a deposit and pays an annual amount until purchase price is completed.

 Domain: Rural

If a portion of the progress payments is remitted by the state to the Southland free-selectors, the practical result will be that they will ultimately obtain their land for a less price than they originally agreed to pay for it.

 freeze-out
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: 
 Origin: 
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
 Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1975  
 Source:  Men of the Milford Road
 Author:  ANDERSON
 Vol / Page:  54
 Edition:  
 Quote:  At the end of the evening someone suggested we finish up with a `freeze out' and this was agreed to. The rules of this form of sport were simple. Each player has to have three threepenny pieces and on the first round all put in one threepence. An ordinary poker hand was then dealt and cards were bought as required. There was no betting as all hands were tabled face up and the man with the worst hand was `frozen out'. All he had to do however, was to put in his second threepence and he was in again. After losing three threepences, however, he was frozen out for good. This

went on until only two players remained and on the final game the winner took the whole kitty!

 Date:  0/7/1986  
 Source:  Metro
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  76
 Edition:  
 Quote:  In 1932, wages were cut, and the freezing workers struck throughout the country. The butchers didn't believe that they could be replaced, but when the works reopened it was found that the

companies had installed the American chain system, with each worker responsible for only one aspect of the process. The butchers were replaced by the unemployed, who initially made a terrible mess of the carcasses. But in time they became competent process workers, as opposed to the tradesmen who had preceded them. <i>Ibid.</i> 86 

The freezing workers sent in a short line-out to meet them: Kennedy and Scott from the New Zealand union, Evans from Auckland and Douglas and Knox from the FOL. 


 Notes:

 Notes:  

 freezing works
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: an abattoir or factory where livestock are slaughtered and their carcasses frozen

 Date:  0/0/1957

 Author:  MACDONALD
 Vol / Page:  77
 Edition:  
 Quote:  From experience of companies now working (in other countries), it is found that the operations can best be carried on by having the freezing works away from the port of shipment but adjacent to a line of railway, ... and where paddocking can be got for holding the stock until slaughtered. 


 Notes:  1881 Dec 21 Report of Committee on Frozen Meat Trade in 1957 Macdonald Canterbury Frozen Meat Company 77
