 Date:  0/0/1926  
 Source:  Weeds of New Zealand
 Author:  HILGENDORF
 Vol / Page:  192
 Edition:  1967
 Quote:  MILK THISTLE (<i>Silybum marianum</i>), sometimes called St. Mary's thistle, variegated or spotted thistle, and, near Akaroa, French thistle ... . It is abundant in scattered localities in both islands, sometimes forming dense masses. It is an annual or biennial, grows up to 6 ft. in height, and has large leaves without wings.

 Frenchman
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: the fish, Kathetostoma giganteum
 Origin: 
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
 Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1956  
 Source:  NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide
 Author:  GRAHAM
 Vol / Page:  286
 Edition:  (2nd edn)
 Quote:  FLATHEAD <i>Kathetostoma giganteum</i> Haast ... Other names for the Flathead are Chinaman and Frenchman, but where these names originated and for what reason I do not know with certainty. One theory is that when Chinamen hawked fish about Dunedin they kept Flatheads for their own consumption, as they preferred them to all other fish. 


 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1981  
 Source:  Fisherman's Bible
 Author:  WILSON
 Vol / Page:  74
 Edition:  
 Quote:  FRENCHMAN: see Flathead <i>Ibid.</i> 100 [The Flathead, <i>Kathetostoma</i> sp. is sometimes called Frenchman or Chinaman (presumably because these fishermen sold them in the early Otago days). The Latin translation of the name means roughly `large, perpendicular mouth.'

Also known as Spotted Stargazer. <i>Ibid.</i> 100 FRENCHMAN Another name for Flathead. Also known as Chinaman. The latter name apparently derives from the fact that Chinese fish merchants in Dunedin in the early days always kept these fish for their own consumption. Nowadays these fish are more accurately termed Spotted Stargazer.

 Date:  0/0/1898  
 Source:  Austral English
 Author:  MORRIS
 Vol / Page:  105
 Edition:  
 Quote:  ~ The Australasian <i>cray-fish</i> belong to the family <i>Parastacida</i>, the members of which are confined to the southern hemisphere, whilst those of the family <i>Potamobiida</i> are found in the northern hemisphere. Victoria; <i>Paranephrops,</i> found in the fresh waters of New Zealand.The species are as follows:- (5) <i>New Zealand Fresh-water Cray-fish</i>. Name applied to <i>Paranephrops zealandicus</i>, white, which is confined to the fresh water of New Zealand.

 freshwater flounder

 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  72

 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1970  
 Source:  Nomenclature of NZ Fish
 Author:  SORENSON
 Vol / Page:  24
 Edition:  
 Quote:  FLOUNDER (four species) (a) Scientific name: (i) <i>Rhombosolea plebeia (ii) Rhombosolea retiaria (iii)  Rhombosolea tapirina (iv) Rhombosolea leporina</i>. (b) Suggested commercial name[s]: (i) Flounder (ii) Freshwater Flounder (iii) Flounder (iv) Yellowbelly Flounder. (c) Other common names: (i) Square, Dab, Plaice, Diamond or Diamond-back, Tin-plate, Three Corners. (ii) Blacks, Black Flounder (iii) Greenback [25 `Not common but occasionally taken in southern

waters.'] (iv) Yellow Flounder. 


 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1981  
 Source:  Fisherman's Bible
 Author:  WILSON
 Vol / Page:  72
 Edition:  
 Quote:  FLOUNDER, BLACK More sole-like in shape than his cousin flounders this fellow also has small, brick-red spots on his back and has the ability - unlike the other flatfish - of being able to live in pure, fresh water. Other names are`River Flounder' and `Mud or Freshwater Flounder'.

 Vol / Page:  144

 Date:  0/0/1947  
 Source:  Native Animals of NZ
 Author:  POWELL
 Vol / Page:  34
 Edition:  
 Quote:  FRESH-WATER MUSSEL (Hyridella menziesi). This or related species or subspecies are found buried in mud in most of our lakes, rivers and streams. They grow from 2 to 4 inches in length, and are covered with a thick dark green horny epidermis.... This is the kakahi of the Maoris, formerly much favoured by them as a special food for young children and the sick.
 Notes:

 fribby
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: adjective
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: Applies to small short locks of wool. Also as n (usu pl), such locks. Also frib (usually pl) short wool pieces and second cuts. 1900 Aust 1915 MacDonald NZ Sheepfarming 26/69 1929 H.B. Smith Sheep and Wool Industry in NZ (ed 3) 209 1951 Ac ECR 379] sc. of wool ?rarely @n

 Quote:  That this Committee concurs in the report

of the Joint Committee on the granting of

the New Zealand War Medal to such of the

Colonial forces and friendly Natives in

all cases where the claimants have been

actually under fire, or otherwise

conspicuous for distinguished service in

the field; and recommends that the medal

be also given to the nearest relatives of

any who have died of wounds or have been

killed in action.

 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1982  
 Source:  Collins Guide
 Author:  AYLING
 Vol / Page:  293
 Edition:  1984
 Quote:  <i>FRIGATE TUNA </i>(Frigate mackerel) <i>Auxis thazard</i> ... The frigate tuna is a slender fish and is the smallest of the tunas found in the New Zealand region ... They are called bullets by tuna fishermen and can cause a great deal of trouble to purse seiners working skipjack schools [by gilling themselves in the net and taking time to remove].
 Notes:

(c) Other common names: (i) Common Mackerel, Frigate mackerel, English mackerel (ii) Horse Mackerel. (d) Principal localities where taken: (both) Gisborne, Nelson, Picton ..

 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1886  
 Source:  TrNZI
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  18/100
 Edition:  
 Quote:  There are thirteen species [of shag] in New Zealand <i>Phalacrocorax novae-hollandiae</i> (Black shag), <i>P. melanoleucus</i> (Frilled Shag), <i>P. brevirostris </i>(White-throated Shag), <i>P. varius </i> Pied shag, and <i>P. punctatus</i> (Spotted Shag), which I have often found in the inland bays, rivers, and lakes. The frilled shag is, owing to its cautious habits, called the `duckscarer' by the sportsmen living in the above - mentioned sound [Kenepuru].

 Definition: usu. boiled tapioca, or tapioca pudding; occas. sago or sago pudding  (cf frog spawn tapioca or sago pudding)
 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]

 front

 Notes:  

 front country
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number:  1
 Definition: farmland consisting of foothills, downs and plains which front the east-side of the Southern Alps and high country land [usually relatively accessible to the station or a road.] 


 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: Rural
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
 Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1940  
 Source:  Te Waimate
 Author:  STUDHOLME
 Vol / Page:  104
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Black pine (matai) was used [for fencing] on the front country but it was not as good as broadleaf, because it rotted away in a few years.
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1981  
 Source:  Loughnan Glossary
 Author:  LOUGHNAN
 Vol / Page:  2

 Quote:  In the South Island that country beyond the river gorges is termed back country, as differing from front country which consists of those hills through whose gorges the same rivers wend their way.

 Quote:  In 1854 a further ten large runs were established on the remainder of the plains between the Ashburton and Rakaia Rivers; this meant that the entire plains and 'front hills' were taken up.

 Source:  Listener (New Zealand Listener)
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  19
 Edition:  
 Quote:  "We've fetished the front lawn," says Dann. "Where else could you call a group the Front Lawn and everyone knew what the joke was?" The front Lawn is now unfortunately concreted over, as it were, but in the garden the concept remains "quintessentially Kiwi; it speaks volumes about our culture"... In New Zealand the front lawn has always been an upwardly mowable status symbol.. but mostly.. front lawns are there to keep people away.

 front lead
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: 
 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
 Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1962  
 Source:  Waikaka Saga
 Author:  EVANS
 Vol / Page:  4
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Immediately north of the [Waikaka] township a rich layer in the fault-involved older quartz drifts, ... was worked from the surface ... This layer is locally known as the `back lead'. On or near it a shaft was sunk ... but was not utilised for driving-out. ... Somewhere about 1880 ...

others drove an inclined drift from point to the southward of the back lead for a distance of 254 feet ... Then they drove horizontally for a short distance and intersected an auriferous ... layer of quartz wash, about 10 feet wide, known as the `front lead'. [fn quotes OED on drift as an excavated passage]
 Notes:  1914 P.G. Morgan report Geological Survey Branch  147 in 1962 Evans Waikaka Saga 4

 Quote:  FROSTFISH  (a) Scientific name: <i>Lepidopus caudatus</i>. (b) Suggested commercial name[s]: Frostfish. (c) Other common names: Frosts or Frosties. (d) Principal localities where taken: Cook Strait and East Coast as far as Napier.

 frost lift
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number:  1
 Definition: needle ice, that occurs when damp or wet bare soil or sub-soil is exposed to alternate warming and cooling. 


 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: Rural
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation:

 Source of soil loss.

 Vol / Page:  29
 Edition:  
 Quote:  FROST FISH (<i>Lepidopus caudatus</i>). ... [30] The frost-fish, or hiku of the Maoris, is esteemed the most delicious fish in New Zealand. It is most commonly found cast up after cold frosty nights on sandy beaches that are exposed to the long roll of ocean swell, and is not in this country obtained by any kind of fishing. <i>Ibid.</i> 300 <i>Lepidopus caudatus</i> Euphrasen Frost-fish, Hiku, or Para.

 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1898  
 Source:  Austral English
 Author:  MORRIS
 Vol / Page:  155
 Edition:  
 Quote:  ~ name given in Australia and New Zealand to the European <i>Scabbard-fish, Lepidopus caudatus</i>, White. The name is said to be derived from the circumstance that the fish is found alive on New Zealand sea-beaches on frosty nights. It is called the <i>Scabbard-fish</i> in Europe, because it is like the shining  white metal sheath of a long sword. <i>Lepidopus</i> belongs to the family <i>Trichiurida</i>; it reaches a length of five or six feet, but is so thin that it hardly weighs as many pounds. It is considered a delicacy in New Zealand. 


 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1888  
 Source:  Birds of New Zealand
 Author:  BULLER
 Vol / Page:   ii./ 51
 Edition:  
 Quote:  ` The frost-fish ... the most delicately flavoured of all New Zealand fishes, is an inhabitant of deep water, and on frosty sights, owing probably to its air-bladders becoming choked, it is cast up be the surf on the ocean-beach.' And in New Zealand to <i>Carpophaga nova-zealandia, </i>

Gmel. (Maori name, <i>Kereru Kuku</i>, or <i>Kukupa.</i>)

<i>Ibid.</i> 73 The frost fish, which has a long, silvery body, is usually picked up on the sea beach in the winter weather;...

 Date:  0/0/1927  
 Source:  Natural History of Canterbury
 Author:  SPEIGHT et al.
 Vol / Page:  199
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The only true mackerels recorded from Canterbury are the Pacific Bonito  (<i>Sarda chiliensis</i>) and the large-scaled Tunny  (<i>Gasterochisma melampus</i>) which may reach a length of 6 feet; but a related family includes the well-known Barracouta  (<i>Thyrsites atun</i>), the King Barracouta, <i> Jordanidia solandrii</i> (often known locally as Kingfish, but not to be confused with the North Island Kingfish which is a form or Yellowtail) and the elongated, silvery-hued frost fish  (<i>Lepidopus caudatus</i>) whose curious stranding habits can hardly yet be said to be satisfactorily explained.  


 Notes:  1927 Archey  `Native Fishes of Canterbury' in Speight et al. Natural History of Canterbury 199

 Vol / Page:  71
 Edition:  
 Quote:  FROST-FISH (<i>Lepidopus caudatus</i>), Para of the Maoris, is like a long narrow ribbon of burnished silver, from 3 to 5 feet in length. They derive their name from the fact that numbers of these fish come ashore around the coast, usually on calm, frosty nights.

 Date:  0/0/1967  
 Source:  Marine Fishes
 Author:  MORELAND
 Vol / Page:  46
 Edition:  
 Quote:  FROSTFISH [<i>Lepidopus caudatus</i>] ... A number of old Maori names are known but are not in use today.
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1967  
 Source:  Animals of NZ, The
 Author:  NATUSCH
 Vol / Page:  225
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Family TRICHIURIDAE. The frost fishes (<i>Lepidopus </i>...) are unrelated to the ribbonfish ... which they superficially resemble. They have no scales. The `silver' which rubs off like aluminium paint is the substance guanin, which gives many fishes their silvery sheen. Nobody can explain <i>Lepidopus</'>s habit of putting itself ashore on cold spring and winter evenings. 


 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1968  
 Source:  NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Collins)
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  9
 Edition:  
 Quote:  <I>frost fish n.</I> long, very thin edible Australian and N.Z.  fish, the European scabbard fish. Maori name <I>Para. </I>
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1970  
 Source:  Nomenclature of NZ Fish
 Author:  SORENSON
 Vol / Page:  25
 Edition:  
 Quote:  FROSTFISH  (a) Scientific name: <I>Lepidopus caudatus</I>. (b) Suggested commercial name[s]: Frostfish. (c) Other common names: Frosts or Frosties. (d) Principal localities where taken: Cook Strait and East Coast as far as Napier.
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1981  
 Source:  Fisherman's Bible
 Author:  WILSON
 Vol / Page:  66
 Edition:  
 Quote:  FROSTFISH <I>Lepidopus caudatus</I>: The Maori name Para means `to spring' or `to leap' and refers to the last moments of the average specimen when it seems tp leave its own element to spring to its death. <I>Lepidopus</I> means `small scales' and <I>caudatus</I> refers to the small tail. It is sometimes called the `Suicide-fish.'
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1982  
 Source:  Collins Guide
 Author:  AYLONG
 Vol / Page:  289
 Edition:  1984
 Quote:  FROSTFISH <I>Lepidopus caudatus</I> ... Frostfish have a scaleless body and are a uniform bright silver colour. They spend the cold winter months in deep offshore water beyond the edge of the continental shelf and apparently come to the surface on clear still nights when the moon is full; although it maybe that they are on the surface at other times but are not seen because of the dull rough conditions. ... They are occasionally found stranded on beaches.


 Notes:  

 Date:  23/7/1986  
 Source:  Codes for Species in NZ Waters
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  
 Edition:  
 Quote:  [species name] frost fish ..[scientific name]  <I>Lepidopus caudatus</I> .. [other name(s)] cutlassfish, scabbardfish
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1986  
 Source:  NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide
 Author:  PAUL
 Vol / Page:  123
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Frostfish <I>Lepidopus caudatus</I> ... A widespread species of temperate oceanic waters, generally simply called scabbard-fish, but known as frostfish in Australia and New Zealand (from the skin's colour which comes off when touched).

 frostpot

 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number:  1
 Definition: a small oil burner used to ''fight'' frost in orchards, particularly in Central Otago. 


 Origin: [none]

 Domain: Rural
 Region: [none]

 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  38
 Edition:  
 Quote:  .. overhead sprinklers offer the cheapest method of frost control in frosty situations. On the other hand, frostpots are the more economical where frosts are few and light. In situations with light frosts, trickle irrigation combined with frostpots is usually the best alternative.

 Date:  11/3/1995

 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  16
 Edition:  
 Quote:  I'm told that someone who would be seen

in politically correct circles as

perspicacity-challenged is immediately

identifiable by his peers if he is

described as a fruitloop. The last time I

rubbed shoulders with fruitloops they

were repulsively sticky little things, in

bright colours. When poured on to a plate

they became a cereal breakfast fit to

brighten the morning of any jaded five-

year-old.

 Date:  0/0/1843  
 Source:  Travels in NZ
 Author:  DIEFFENBACH
 Vol / Page:  1/121
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The hills are steep, covered with leptospermum, tall fuchsias with purple flowers, Edwardsias, and other shrubs. <i>Ibid.</i> 1/122  There are two fuchsias here: one, the <I>Fuchsia excorticata</I>, forms a moderate-sized tree, and is very common; the other, however, the <I>Fuchsia procumbens</I>, is very rare, and at present is met with only in Wangaroa Bay, to the northward of the Bay of Islands.

 Vol / Page:  87

 Quote:   ... such species as lancewood, karamu, toro, ramarama, koromiko, kanono, kohuhu, kawakawa, hangehange, rangiora, five finger, patete, toru, tree daisies, broadleaf, kamahi, mahoe, tarata, karo, lacebark, wineberry, fuchsia, kowhai, with tree ferns, weki, and mamuku. Toetoe, phormium, cabbage tree, with swamp coprosma and hupiro may figure as a developmental phase on wet soils.

 Vol / Page:  156

 Quote:  <i>Fuchsia, Native</i>, n. <i>The name is applied to several native plants.</i> ...  (3) In New Zealand, to <i>Fuchsia excorticata </I>, Linn.,  N.O. <I>Onagrariae</I>. (Maori name, <i>Kotukutuku</i>, (q.v.)  See also <i>Tooky-took</i> and <i>Konini. </i>


 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1900  
 Source:  Canterbury Old & New
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  184
 Edition:  
 Quote:  The native fuchsia  [fn <i>Fuchsia excorticata.</i>] - an exile from South America - and the fierce bush-nettle  [fn <i>Urtica ferox</i>.] are conspicuous amongst the undergrowth, together with the bush-lily  [fn <i>Astelia nervosa</i>.], but we see but few species of the characteristic New Zealand daisy-trees  [fn Species of <i>Olearia</i>.] or of the bushy Veronicas (koromiko), which are so conspicuous in other parts of these islands.

 Date:  0/0/1972  
 Source:  Folkgames of Children
 Author:  SUTTON-SMITH
 Vol / Page:  175
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Some of the typical terms used in marbles referred to the act of shooting and the movement of the marbles. Those related to ways of shooting marbles were cribbing, firsts, fudging, funks, funnicks, funnigans, flunks, forces, knee-high, knuckle-down-stiff, knuckles, and lasts. Terms connected with the movement of the marbles were: cannons, clears, dead-stick, double-hits, fires, funs, gees, haystacks, in smug, keeps, kills, kisses, lay-ups, manyes, ones, pink, ringer, rolls, scat, screws, skinned, skun, spiders, sported-off, stays, stops, tracks, throughs.

 Source:  Adventuring in Maoriland in the Seventies
 Author:  MEREDITH
 Vol / Page:  81
 Edition:  1935
 Quote:  Mrs Dougal [a Dunedin Presbyterian] ... gave her lawful spouse a particularly bad time if and when he returned home anyway fou' ... 
 Notes:  

 full
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: adjective
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: construed with blast, bore, lick, out, split, swing, to form phrasal adverbs with the sense `at full speed'; `energetically'; `flat out', of speed, activity of any kind (cf OED FULL 9c)
 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
 Notes: 
 Citations 
 full (of)
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: adjective
 Sense Number: 2
 Definition: fed up (with)
 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
 Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1881  
 Source:  Chequered Career
 Author:  NESFIELD
 Vol / Page:  38
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Although, there were plenty of station horses, ... I invested in a couple for my own private use. ... [One] bucked me off more times than I can remember, and I began to get `full' of him. George, my mate, proposed Rarey-fying him. The process consisted in breathing up his nose ... One of Rarey's theories was that the breath of man inhaled into the horse's nostrils intimidated him. 
 Notes:

 Author:  CHARLES
 Vol / Page:  89
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Young Bradshaw's the boy who is flying this plane,/ She is as full as a tick and it's pouring with rain./ Things are not going good - his donk's on the blink* -/ Then he puts up a blue and she dives in the drink./ [fn] *his donk's on the blink: his engine is giving trouble (airman's slang) [Charles had served in the RNZAF in WW2]

 full board
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number:  1
 Definition: a full number of shearers occupying every available stand in a woolshed.

 full mouth
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: a sheep or cattle beast with eight erupted incisor teeth.

 Domain: Rural

 full on
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: adjective
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: fed up (with);  weary of (cf full (up) of)
 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
 Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1881  
 Source:  Waitaruna
 Author:  BATHGATE
 Vol / Page:  151
 Edition:  
 Quote:  `This is no go, and we must give it best! ... I think it's time to cry `Smoke oh' and then we'll go up, for I'm full on this shooting racket.'  `You are adept at slang, Arthur, and no mistake', ...  `And yet a fellow told me the other day, he could tell at once that I had not been long in the country, or, as he phrased it, `that I had not got the lime-juice out of me yet;' so it can't be colonial slang that I speak.'  Well, I don't know that colonials are worse than other people for speaking slang, but they have, of course, many words and phrases peculiar to themselves.'  
 Notes:

 Notes:  

 full up
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: adjective
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: tired (of), fed up (with)
 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
 Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1892  
 Source:  Homeward Bound
 Author:  REEVES
 Vol / Page:  33
 Edition:  
 Quote:  I note the men have to do all the fielding and get tired, or as the colonial slang goes, `full up', soonest.
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1929  
 Source:  Whitcombe's Etym. Dict. Aust-NZ Suppl.
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  4
 Edition:  
 Quote:  full a.-full up' a. sl. of. tired of.
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1937  
 Source:  Dictionary of Slang
 Author:  PARTRIDGE
 Vol / Page:  307
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Full up 2. (Constructed with of) sated; weary; disgusted: Australian and, later, New Zealand, from ca. 1890. Rolf Boldrewood in The Miner's Right. Variants full (if followed by of), full on (with object). Cf. fed up (with), q.v., the English counterpart. 
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1988  
 Source:  Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A
 Author:  McGILL
 Vol / Page:  47
 Edition:  
 Quote:  full up exasperated, weary, disgusted; eg `I'm full up with this shower, Netty. Let's split.' NZA. b. full up of
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1898  
 Source:  Austral English
 Author:  MORRIS
 Vol / Page:  156
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Full up of, adj. (slang), sick and tired of. `Full on,' and `full of' are other forms.' [1890] 
 Notes:

 Notes:  1879 May 30 Peache Jnl in 1970 Gray Quiet with the Hills 58 .

 Date:  0/0/1987  
 Source:  Boards, Blades & Barebellies
 Author:  OGONOWSKA-COATES
 Vol / Page:  94
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Ages of sheep. Although there are many variations, the following names are usually used: A  sheep is a lamb until weaned. After weaning a lamb  is called a hogget until shorn. A male lamb is a  ram lamb until castrated, then a wether. A female  lamb is a ewe lamb. After shearing, a ewe or ram  lamb is usually called a shorn hogget until cutting the first two teeth. It is then called a two-tooth. Some use the term two-tooth as soon as the lamb is shorn. Next year the sheep is a four-tooth, then a six-tooth and then an eight-tooth or full-mouthed sheep. It is full-mouthed as long as the teeth remain perfect but then becomes broken-mouthed and gummy. 
 Notes:

 Fun Ho
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: A brand of metal toys, like Dinky Toys, but of initially cruder construction, made originally of lead  and then aluminium in Wellington by Harold Underwood in the 1930. In 1945 production moved to New Plymouth and in 1949 to Inglewood where they were made until 1982.
 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
 Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  31/12/2003  
 Source:  Dominion Post
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  C2
 Edition:  
 Quote:  A rugged brightly painted Fun Ho! toy in Santa's stocking on Christmas morning was a surprise bringing approving smiles to the faces of Kiwi kids for generations.... Harold (Jack) Underwood made lead slush tops and semiflat figures in his basement as a hobby, unaware that those experiments would become the success that enabled him to resign from the public service and enter the toy-making business... There is an absolutely positively Wellington origin about the distinctive Fun Ho! trademark, too. The design with exclamation nmark was by the late E Mervyn Taylor, a New Zealand arrist who worked in the city at the same time as an illustrator and commercial artist... The earliest Fun Ho! models were made from lead and appear to have been produced in Wellington.
 Notes:

 Date:  0/0/1940

 Edition:  1988
 Quote:  Often when household funds were low, a few shillings were obtained by selling fungus, otherwise known as `Taranaki Wool,' which was purchased by Chinese dealers ...
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1952  
 Source:  Chatham Islands
 Author:  RICHARDS
 Vol / Page:  145
 Edition:  
 Quote:  At one time Jacobs leased about 2000 acres of the usually useless [Chatham] Tobacco Country. He wanted it for the fungus that grew so abundantly on the kopi trees which formed the main portion of that forest. This he gathered to export to China. The very large, soft circular fungus could also be induced to grow on logs and roots split open and placed in an old tin shed. There copious watering soon covered everything with the huge white growth and all Jacobs had to do was to pull it off the logs and spread it out to dry. A pile a foot or so high would only yield a few handfuls of dry chips. When ready for packing it had to be damped once more to keep it from turning into powder. It never went mouldy because it was a mould to start with. When first sent abroad the Islanders got 4d. a pound for it, later only 2d. Even at that price they stripped the forests and killed the goose. Jacobs seems to have been the only one who attempted to cultivate it. The Chinese used it for soup (it makes a thick, sticky, rather tasteless fluid when boiled), dressing silk and varnish.
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1960  
 Source:  Ernie and the Rest of Us
 Author:  BOSWELL
 Vol / Page:  137
 Edition:

 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See:

 Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/12/1922  
 Source:  NZ Journal of Science & Technology
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  5/427
 Edition:  
 Quote:  <I>CLATHRUS CIBARIUS</I>, THE `BIRD-CAGE FUNGUS'. ... This fungus, known variously as `basket fungus,'`lattice fungus,', `Devil's purse,' <I> `tutae whetu,' `tutae kehua</I>,' belongs to the Phallaceae, a family included in the Basidiomycetes. It is found commonly throughout New Zealand during the late autumn and early spring. [Distribution.- Australia; Chile; ... New Zealand]
 Notes:   (Cunningham)

 Quote:  <i>Nidula candida</i> BIRDSNEST FUNGUS ... Tiny cups on dead wood or twigs ... with brown pellets of spore-bearing tissue nestling within, like eggs in a nest.

 Date:  0/0/1966  
 Source:  Maori Life and Custom
 Author:  PHILLIPPS
 Vol / Page:  61
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Little has been recorded of the bracket fungus  [<i>Polyporus</i>] and its importance in the generation of fire. ... Dr G.B. Cone has spoken to an old Pakeha bushman who has used it in the Thames district where it was known as `punk' to the early settlers, who learned of its use from the Maoris. Punk burns very slowly and persistently. It can be put out only when smothered. ... Punk has now been recognised as the  dried flesh of the <i>Polyporus hosularus </i>which may be found in many parts of the North Island.

 Source:  NZ Journal of Science & Technology
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  5/247
 Edition:  
 Quote:  <I>CLATHRUS CIBARIUS</I>, THE `BIRD-CAGE FUNGUS'. ... This fungus, known variously as `basket fungus,'`lattice fungus,', `Devil's purse,' <I> `tutae whetu,' `tutae kehua</I>,' belongs to the Phallaceae, a family included in the Basidiomycetes. It is found commonly throughout New Zealand during the late autumn and early spring. [Distribution.- Australia; Chile; ... New Zealand]

 Notes:  

 funk
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: verb
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: funking vbl n -->(in marbles) childrens for encroaching your given mark, or not shooting with knuckles on the ground, or otherwise breaking a set rule; to cheat -->ca1930 NZ
 Origin: 
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
 Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1972  
 Source:  Folkgames of Children
 Author:  SUTTON-SMITH
 Vol / Page:  176
 Edition:  
 Quote:  [Waitara, Taranaki, 1899: reference, game of Little Ring] Many heated arguments arose as to who said `everythings' or `nothings' first. If a player's `taw' touched a marble and lay alongside it, the others would shout `knuckle down' just before his turn. ... `Knuckle down' meant that the player had to hold his taw close to the marble attacked and fire it in that very inconvenient position. ... When a boy lost all his marbles at play he was `scat' [?related to skint ?HWO] . ... A `ringer' was a taw which, when fired at the commencement of the game, lodged in the track of the ring itself; that, and knocking a marble out when he `fired' were the perfect shots. ... To fire a shot while holding the hand nearer to the ring than where the taw had lain, was to `funk', an unforgiveable crime.
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1933  
 Source:  Tides of Youth
 Author:  SCANLAN
 Vol / Page:  153
 Edition:  
 Quote:   `Reverend Mother talks of when she used to give you marbles for being a good little boy - pee-wees and agates, and stonies and glassies and a big tor. And once she tried to play with you, and you said she funked because her knuckle was inside the ring.'

 Source:  History of Children's Play
 Author:  SUTTON-SMITH
 Vol / Page:  269
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Here are some [marble] terms from Taranaki around 1880-1890: firsts, lay-up, stakes, tips, sticking-taw, nothings, anythings, fade-it, knuckledown stiff, dubs, finking [sic, ?funking], sips, spanning, placing; and from Dunedin School in 1949: knee high, manyies, tracks, screws, nuts, sleets, kills, forces, dig, dubs, cheats.

 funks
 Homonym Number:

 Sense Number: 
 Definition: 
 Origin: 
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
 Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1953  
 Source:  Unorganized Games
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  2/769
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Action terms which refer to the shooting of the marbles are: Knuckle down Stiff, Knee High, Funks [Flunks sic] or Funnicks, Slips, Firsts and Lasts and Forces. ... The term `Knuckle down Stiff' (Taranaki [18]80, Gisborne [18]85, Waitara [18]95) is mentioned by [Lady A.B. Gomme Vo. 1, p.113]. ... As Taranaki [18]80 says, `The term was called out in order to prevent too easy a success against a marble near the ring'. It was less advantageous to fire with the hand on the ground than with the hand elevated, perhaps at `Knee High'. 
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1972  
 Source:  Folkgames of Children
 Author:  SUTTON-SMITH
 Vol / Page:  175
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Some of the typical terms used in marbles referred to the act of shooting and the movement of the marbles. Those related to ways of shooting marbles were cribbing, firsts, fudging, funks, funnicks, funnigans, flunks, forces, knee-high, knuckle-down-stiff, knuckles, and lasts. Terms connected with the movement of the marbles were: cannons, clears, dead-stick, double-hits, fires, funs, gees, haystacks, in smug, keeps, kills, kisses, lay-ups, manyes, ones, pink, ringer, rolls, scat, screws, skinned, skun, spiders, sported-off, stays, stops, tracks, throughs.  
 Notes:

 funs
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: exclamation
 Sense Number: 2
 Definition: a cry when playing marbles for keeps, to indicate that the shot in progress is not for `keeps', or that after the game the marbles won have to be handed back; the expressions are `funs or keeps.' Sometimes pron funds 
 Origin: 
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
 Notes: 
 Citations

 Author:  FRAME
 Vol / Page:  116
 Edition:  1961
 Quote:  `Treasure' I played ringie and holie. I played funs and keeps. I had pee-wees and bully taws and changers that weren't made of glass mind you. And I won nearly every game because the kids were so dazzled by the look of my stinkers. ... They came for miles to play marbles with me ... 
 Notes:  

 funs
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: a game (esp. marbles) not played seriously, `for keeps', or to strictly agreed rules

 Quote:  The bewhiskered New Zealand fur seal and Hector's sea lion were almost exterminated and have taken 150 years to come back. <i>Ibid.</i> 27 The Bountys are just a pile of lichened rocks, yellow tide-line bull kept their only vegetation. Discovered by Bligh in 1788 and ignored for 30 years, their New Zealand fur seals were then exploited mercilessly.

 futtah
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number:  1
 Definition: a station store [alteration of Maori whata.] 
 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: Rural
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
 Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  0/0/1986  
 Source:  NZ Heritage of Farm Buildings
 Author:  THORNTON
 Vol / Page:  245
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Acland has defined the term "futtah" as a "station store built on high posts to keep rats and mice out. Both name and design are borrowed from the Maori." In the South Island especially this name, a corruption from "whata" was quite common. ..E S Elwell, who refers to the structure at Papakaio near Oamaru as "the futtah, or store, weatherboarded, and with a shingle roof...."
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1981  
 Source:  Loughnan Glossary
 Author:  LOUGHNAN
 Vol / Page:  34
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Futtah: A food store built on high posts so as to deny entry to rats and mice. This system was learned from the Maoris and the word is a corruption of their whata. Pronunciation has also corrupted into watty.
 Notes:  

 Date:  0/0/1986  
 Source:  NZ Heritage of Farm Buildings
 Author:  THORNTON
 Vol / Page:  246
 Edition:  
 Quote:  One of the very few survivors of the true futtah raised high on piles is that of Orari Gorge station.. The futtah is clad in weatherboards..
 Notes:

 fuzzy melon
 Homonym Number:  
 Word Class: noun
 Sense Number: 
 Definition: the Asian gourd Benincasa hispida
 Origin: [none]
 Register: 
 Register 2: 
 Domain: [none]
 Region: [none]
 See: 
 Pronunciation: 
 Notes: 
 Citations 
 Date:  15/3/2003  
 Source:  Dominion Post
 Author:  
 Vol / Page:  F7
 Edition:  
 Quote:  Fuzzy melon (<i>Benincasa hispida</i>). This species of gourd was everywhere at the Victoria St market last week, but only Asian people appeared to be buying it. The fuzzy melon is aptly named - its surface needs to look like it is carrying a bristly two-day growth, otherwise you know it has been picked too old. A Chinese friend told me fuzzy melon is good for taking on the flavours of whatever it is cooked with.
 Notes:
